commit_message:
Sync jsonutils for namedtuple_as_object fix

This is to pull in the fix for bug 1361230 which was introduced
with a prior sync of jsonutils.

strutils is pulled in as a dependency but also fixes an
unrelated bug 1345233.

Changes:

jsonutils
---------
d9060f6 Check for namedtuple_as_object support before using it

strutils
--------
66142c3 Make strutils.mask_password more secure

Change-Id: I9bd2e5f93c2684203487627f64f70d5da7b13586
Closes-Bug: #1361230
Partial-Bug: #1345233

commit_message:
Reuse disable_rollback on stack update

If disable_rollback API parameter is not supplied to stack update,
use corresponding value of existing stack.

Change-Id: Iad60e12d31dc3850071dc0b8562c7b99f53adba4
Closes-Bug: #1324366

commit_message:
Migrate advanced server network to tempest clients

Server is now dict. Changes all related methods accordingly.

Also, moved precondition checks from setUpClass to the appropriate method

Partially-implements: bp:tempest-client-scenarios

Change-Id: I2ad10c3a095b5e326579edfde83d7abcfe077fba

commit_message:
handles keyboard interrupt

When an user intentionally provides an keyboard interrupt, heatclient
throws the entire traceback on to the terminal instead of handling it.

heatclient will now handle the keyboard interrrupt and provides an crisp
message on to the terminal.

Change-Id: Iaa30048e7948d7db1d5b256dd59ca2e0dd842df9
Closes-Bug: #1367283
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/40/120440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except KeyboardInterrupt: print("... terminating heat client", file=sys.stderr) sys.exit(130)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-11 19:52:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency/commit/117e703548292cc48b25365e6af65213c34cb93b', 'message': 'Clarify logging in lockutils

The old logging statements in lockutils made for some confusing log
entries where it would appear a given lock was acquired multiple
times by different threads at the same time.  See referenced bug
for details.

In order to alleviate that confusion, this change does a few things:
1) Adds an explicit "acquired" message inside the lock so it is

2) Moves the release message inside the semaphore so there's no

3) Removes the "Got semaphore" message and splits it into two
   separate messages depending on whether the semaphore was found

   was followed should help with future debugging.

commit_message:
Clarify logging in lockutils

The old logging statements in lockutils made for some confusing log
entries where it would appear a given lock was acquired multiple
times by different threads at the same time.  See referenced bug
for details.

In order to alleviate that confusion, this change does a few things:
1) Adds an explicit "acquired" message inside the lock so it is
   clear when the lock was actually acquired.
2) Moves the release message inside the semaphore so there's no
   chance of it being logged out of order.
3) Removes the "Got semaphore" message and splits it into two
   separate messages depending on whether the semaphore was found
   in the weakref dictionary.  Making it clear which code path
   was followed should help with future debugging.

Change-Id: I0fbb473c60d48c9704597d9e3634402857861a66
Closes-Bug: 1367941
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency refs/changes/94/120894/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: LOG.debug('Got semaphore "%(lock)s"', {'lock': name}) LOG.debug('Released semaphore "%(lock)s"', {'lock': name})

commit_message:
Allow FWaaS API test to accept more than one end state

To support distributed routers, it is useful to have this API tempest test
to accept a firewall resource to be either in ACTIVE or CREATED state. After
all, this is not a scenario test, so whether the resoure is actually wired
should be irrelevant.

Closes-bug: #1360351

Change-Id: I2367c2877ca2ebabc08095b33a85659de2b882bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/77/116377/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def _wait_for_active(self, fw_id): return firewall['status'] == 'ACTIVE' m = 'Timed out waiting for firewall %s to become ACTIVE.' % fw_id self._wait_for_active(firewall_id)

subject: Big Switch: Retry on 503 errors from backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-14 22:39:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/33cd9fb6bbbb336d6d8310f2f1a85f090bd62818', 'message': 'Big Switch: Retry on 503 errors from backend

Retries requests to the backend controller up to 3
additional times with 3 seconds in between each request
if a 503 service unavailable message was returned.
The scenarios that return 503 messages from floodlight
are normally short lived locks for things like OpenStack
synchronization or upgrade blocks. Retrying should work
in the majority of cases.

Closes-Bug: #1357105

commit_message:
Big Switch: Retry on 503 errors from backend

Retries requests to the backend controller up to 3
additional times with 3 seconds in between each request
if a 503 service unavailable message was returned.
The scenarios that return 503 messages from floodlight
are normally short lived locks for things like OpenStack
synchronization or upgrade blocks. Retrying should work
in the majority of cases.

Closes-Bug: #1357105
Change-Id: Ifacd3a384cfc797ba6d6af5f3c8649c333473259
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/79/114379/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import timeSERVICE_UNAVAILABLE_RETRY_COUNT = 3 SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE_RETRY_INTERVAL = 3 retries = 0 while ret[0] == httplib.SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE: if retries >= SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE_RETRY_COUNT: break time.sleep(SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE_RETRY_INTERVAL) ret = active_server.rest_call(action, resource, data, headers, timeout, reconnect=self.always_reconnect, hash_handler=hash_handler) retries += 1

commit_message:
Pass kwargs to auth plugins

Auth plugins must sometimes affect the Headers and other portions
of the network setup.  Examples:  Kerberos needs to set the
negotiate header.  X509 to provide the client certificate.

This change makes that capability available to the Auth plugins.

Those plugins will live in separate repositories. There are no
dependent patches for it in this repository.

This was split out by Adam Young from the Kerberos Client patch
written by Jose Castro Leon

Change-Id: Iab7287888e4b3f199b9035c1a24ac43639b5027b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/83/120883/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
trustor_user_id not available in v2 trust token

The trust information in the v2 token is missing the trustor_user_id
and impersonation values. This means you are unable to tell who gave
you the trust.

Change-Id: I7ed215b3353079d8ed9514c586d256c1226a2c19
Closes-bug: #1331882
DocImpact

commit_message:
Handle invalid JSON filters from the input gracefully

When there is a invalid JSON string on the input for e.g. query-alarm-history
at present the exception raised is un-caught causing a internal error
with a HTTP error 500 returned to the client. This fix will handle those
errors and return 400 error with proper message indicating the failure.

Change-Id: Icd81a88f2c29a8baf7993325bf423435f1ad0924
Closes-Bug: 1366215

commit_message:
Fix config generator to use keystonemiddleware

The auth_token middleware was moved from keystoneclient.middleware
to keystonemiddleware. The config generator is configured to point
to the new location.

Closes-Bug: #1366594
Change-Id: I5543973b2c7ac06c048686c24354ecf6eb251027
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/46/119646/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
update autoscaling example with floating ip for lb pool

this patch updates autoscaling.yaml to (a) require an
external_network_id parameter and (b) to allocate a floating ip address
and associate it with the loadbalancer pool.

it adds a website_url output to make it consisent with some of the other
Wordpress examples.

Change-Id: I2669f51145fc6fbf20da831995acfa17e9291f66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/31/119431/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: external_network_id: type: string description: UUID of a Neutron external network # assign a floating ip address to the load balancer # pool. lb_floating: type: "OS::Neutron::FloatingIP" properties: floating_network_id: {get_param: external_network_id} port_id: {get_attr: [pool, vip, port_id]} website_url: value: str_replace: template: http://host/wordpress/ params: host: { get_attr: [lb_floating, floating_ip_address] } description: > This URL is the "external" URL that can be used to access the Wordpress site.

commit_message:
Delete expired objects in slightly smarter way.

When the expirer tries to delete customer objects, if it just walks through the
containers in order the deamon will tend to send DELETEs to the same container
highly concurrently. This will in turn create a lot of asyncs because of all
the concurrent deletes. If the deletes were spread out to multiple containers
it would improve performance and decrease the number of asyncs made.

Change-Id: I3d08118c197b7f18dd7e880bd5664508934ffd24

commit_message:
Cleanup neutron default security groups on tenant deletion

This fix cleanups tenant default security groups that are
automatically created and must be deleted on tenant deletion

Change-Id: Ifcf5ec0391799110f158d113f1b6db8a55a31da9
Closes-Bug: #1283083
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/75/79275/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._cleanup_default_secgroup(tenant) def _cleanup_default_secgroup(self, tenant): net_client = self.network_admin_client if self.tempest_client: resp, resp_body = net_client.list_security_groups(tenant_id=tenant, name="default") else: resp_body = net_client.list_security_groups(tenant_id=tenant, name="default") secgroups_to_delete = resp_body['security_groups'] for secgroup in secgroups_to_delete: try: net_client.delete_security_group(secgroup['id']) except Exception: pass

commit_message:
Replace confusing member name

Replace the member name 'data' in test_object_slo.py and
test_object_temp_url_negative.py with 'content', because 'data' member
is used as a class member name for the instace of DataGenerator in the parent
BaseObjectTest class.

Change-Id: I24f102531afaffd7e797e588777d4621be7a1084
Closes-bug: #1276835

subject: Restrict keystone cross-tenant ACLs to IDs
revisions:
[{'number': 7, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/77b402e9f27f19eb69fd7723f67eab1afd78eba0', 'message': "Restrict keystone cross-tenant ACLs to IDs

The keystoneauth middleware supports cross-tenant access
control using the syntax <tenant>:<user> in container ACLs,
where <tenant> and <user> may be either a unique id or a
name. The keystone v3 API introduces the notion of domains -
names are unique within domains but no longer globally unique.
The use of unqualified tenant and user names in this ACL
syntax is therefore not 'safe' in a keystone v3 environment,
and we do not believe it is possible to unambiguously express
domain name qualification using the existing syntax.

This patch modifies keystoneauth middleware to detect when an
auth token has been validated against the keystone v3 API, and
if so restrict the cross-tenant ACL matching to use only ids.
(Note that authtoken middleware will only validate a token
against the v3 keystone API if explicity configured to
do so using the option auth_version = v3.0).

A keystoneauth config option is provided for users who wish
to override this behaviour and continue to match names
in ACLs.

This change obviously impacts users accustomed to specifying
cross-tenant ACLs in terms of names, and further work will be
necessary to restore those use cases. Some ideas are
discussed under the bug report. With that caveat, this patch
removes the reported vulnerability when using
swift/keystoneauth with a keystone v3 API.

Closes-Bug:  #1299146

Change-Id: Ib32df093f7450f704127da77ff06b595f57615cb

commit_message:
Restrict keystone cross-tenant ACLs to IDs

The keystoneauth middleware supports cross-tenant access
control using the syntax <tenant>:<user> in container ACLs,
where <tenant> and <user> may currently be either a unique
id or a name. As a result of the keystone v3 API introducing
domains, names are no longer globally unique and are only
unique within a domain. The use of unqualified tenant and
user names in this ACL syntax is therefore not 'safe' in a
keystone v3 environment.

This patch modifies keystoneauth to restrict cross-tenant
ACL matching to use only ids for accounts that are not in
the default domain. For backwards compatibility,
names will still be matched in ACLs when both the requesting
user and tenant are known to be in the default domain AND the
account's tenant is also in the default domain (the default
domain being the domain to which existing tenants are
migrated).

Accounts existing prior to this patch are assumed to be for
tenants in the default domain. New accounts created using a
v2 token scoped on the tenant are also assumed to be in the
default domain. New accounts created using a v3 token scoped
on the tenant will learn their domain membership from the
token info. New accounts created using any unscoped token,
(i.e. with a reselleradmin role) will have unknown domain
membership and therefore be assumed to NOT be in the default
domain.

Despite this provision for backwards compatibility, names
must no longer be used when setting new ACLs in any account,
including new accounts in the default domain.

This change obviously impacts users accustomed to specifying
cross-tenant ACLs in terms of names, and further work will be
necessary to restore those use cases. Some ideas are
discussed under the bug report. With that caveat, this patch
removes the reported vulnerability when using
swift/keystoneauth with a keystone v3 API.

Note: to observe the new 'restricted' behaviour you will need
to setup keystone user(s) and tenant(s) in a non-default domain
and set auth_version = v3.0 in the auth_token middleware config
section of proxy-server.conf. You may also benefit from the
keystone v3 enabled swiftclient patch under review here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91788/

DocImpact

blueprint keystone-v3-support

Closes-Bug:  #1299146

Change-Id: Ib32df093f7450f704127da77ff06b595f57615cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/30/86430/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: allow_unqualified_names_in_acls = false The keystoneauth middleware supports cross-tenant access control using the syntax <tenant>:<user> in container Access Control Lists (ACLs). When handling requests validated against a keystone v2 API, keystoneauth will match tenant/user ids AND names in ACLs. When handling requests validated against a keystone v3 API, keystoneauth will NOT match tenant/user names in cross-tenant access control lists, since names are no longer guaranteed to be globally unique. This behavior may be overridden by setting the option ``allow_unqualified_names_in_acls`` in your config: allow_unqualified_names_in_acls = true Names will then be matched in cross-tenant ACLs regardless of the keystone API version.This is not recommended - you should only set this option if you are confident that tenant and user names are globally unique in your system, and will remain so. allow_names = conf.get('allow_unqualified_names_in_acls') self.allow_names_in_acls = swift_utils.config_true_value(allow_names) 'roles': roles, 'auth_version': '2'} if environ.get('HTTP_X_USER_DOMAIN_ID'): identity.update( {'user_domain': (environ.get('HTTP_X_USER_DOMAIN_ID'), environ.get('HTTP_X_USER_DOMAIN_NAME')), 'project': (environ.get('HTTP_X_PROJECT_ID'), environ.get('HTTP_X_PROJECT_NAME')), 'project_domain': (environ.get('HTTP_X_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID'), environ.get('HTTP_X_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME')), 'auth_version': '3'}) tenant_id, tenant_name, roles, allow_names=True): :param allow_names: If True then attempt to match tenant and user names as well as id's. tenant_match = [tenant_id, '*'] user_match = [user_id, '*'] if allow_names: tenant_match = tenant_match + [tenant_name] user_match = user_match + [user_name] for tenant in tenant_match: for user in user_match: self.logger.debug('Using env_identity: %r', env_identity) allow_names = (self.allow_names_in_acls or env_identity['auth_version'] == '2') roles, allow_names)
deleted_lines: 'roles': roles} tenant_id, tenant_name, roles): for tenant in [tenant_id, tenant_name, '*']: for user in [user_id, user_name, '*']: roles)

commit_message:
Fix FormPOST max_file_size exceeded bug.

When using FormPOST, if the size of the file being posted exceeds
max_file_size, a HTTP 499 was being returned rather than HTTP 400.

Change-Id: I48c781735c66eccde3deb6f9c3c184aee964a4a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/77/119877/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.file_size_exceeded = False self.file_size_exceeded = True self.file_size_exceeded = True return [body] wsgi_input = subenv['wsgi.input'] def _start_response(status, headers, exc_info=None): if wsgi_input.file_size_exceeded: raise EOFError("max_file_size exceeded")

commit_message:
Have the EC2 instance test to wait for termination

Several EC2 test did not waited for instance termination.
This change adds an explicit wait for termination,
for the test cases which wants to terminate
the instance inside the test case.

The #1365831 happened because the 'test_run_terminate_instance',
did not waited for the final termination.

Change-Id: Icd3b86ebc8464bd20319e8582541d78fded10ee2
Closes-Bug: #1365831

commit_message:
ceilometer spamming syslog

regression in code which causes ceilometer to spam syslog. this
patch explicitly configures log_level in ceilometer swift
middleware as we no longer rely on swift middleware logic to
configure it.

Change-Id: I248040cb1d842cf89ed32ef28d8575012d36e08f
Closes-Bug: #1367880

commit_message:
Update oslo log module

Changes -
 * Set stevedore log level to WARN by default
 * Add unicode coercion of logged messages to ContextFormatter
 * Correct coercion of logged message to unicode
 * Except socket.error if syslog isn't running
 * Fix E126 pep8 errors
 * Set keystonemiddleware and routes.middleware to log on WARN level
 * Adjust oslo logging to provide adapter is enabled for
 * Make logging_context_format_string optional in log.set_defaults
 * Add default log level for websocket

Change-Id: Ib0529a52c1b6f6328b1022c4a61da752258d01f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/59/120759/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import socket_PY26 = sys.version_info[0:2] == (2, 6) 'urllib3.connectionpool=WARN', 'websocket=WARN', "keystonemiddleware=WARN", "routes.middleware=WARN", "stevedore=WARN"] def isEnabledFor(self, level): if _PY26: # This method was added in python 2.7 (and it does the exact # same logic, so we need to do the exact same logic so that # python 2.6 has this capability as well). return self.logger.isEnabledFor(level) else: return super(BaseLoggerAdapter, self).isEnabledFor(level) # NOTE(jecarey): If msg is not unicode, coerce it into unicode # before it can get to the python logging and # possibly cause string encoding trouble if not isinstance(msg, six.text_type):def set_defaults(logging_context_format_string=None, if default_log_levels is not None: cfg.set_defaults( if logging_context_format_string is not None: cfg.set_defaults( log_opts, logging_context_format_string=logging_context_format_string) if CONF.use_syslog: try: facility = _find_facility_from_conf() # TODO(bogdando) use the format provided by RFCSysLogHandler # after existing syslog format deprecation in J if CONF.use_syslog_rfc_format: syslog = RFCSysLogHandler(facility=facility) else: syslog = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(facility=facility) log_root.addHandler(syslog) except socket.error: log_root.error('Unable to add syslog handler. Verify that syslog' 'is running.') # NOTE(jecarey): If msg is not unicode, coerce it into unicode # before it can get to the python logging and # possibly cause string encoding trouble if not isinstance(record.msg, six.text_type): record.msg = six.text_type(record.msg)
deleted_lines: 'urllib3.connectionpool=WARN'] # NOTE(mrodden): catch any Message/other object and # coerce to unicode before they can get # to the python logging and possibly # cause string encoding trouble if not isinstance(msg, six.string_types):def set_defaults(logging_context_format_string, if default_log_levels is None: default_log_levels = DEFAULT_LOG_LEVELS cfg.set_defaults( logging_context_format_string=logging_context_format_string, if CONF.use_syslog: facility = _find_facility_from_conf() # TODO(bogdando) use the format provided by RFCSysLogHandler # after existing syslog format deprecation in J if CONF.use_syslog_rfc_format: syslog = RFCSysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility) else: syslog = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility) log_root.addHandler(syslog)

Update oslo jsonutils module

 * Specify namedtuple_as_object=False when using simplejson

added_lines: is_simplejson = False # NOTE(mriedem): Make sure we have a new enough version of simplejson # to support the namedobject_as_tuple argument. This can be removed # in the Kilo release when python 2.6 support is dropped. if 'namedtuple_as_object' in inspect.getargspec(json.dumps).args: is_simplejson = True else: import json if is_simplejson: kwargs['namedtuple_as_object'] = False if is_simplejson: kwargs['namedtuple_as_object'] = False

'[\'"]).*?([\'"])', r'(%(key)s\s*--?[A-z]+\s*)\S+(\s*)'] for pattern in _FORMAT_PATTERNS_2: _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_2.append(reg_ex) for pattern in _FORMAT_PATTERNS_1: reg_ex = re.compile(pattern % {'key': key}, re.DOTALL) _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_1.append(reg_ex) substitute = r'\g<1>' + secret + r'\g<2>' for pattern in _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_2: message = re.sub(pattern, substitute, message) substitute = r'\g<1>' + secret for pattern in _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_1: message = re.sub(pattern, substitute, message)

commit_message:
Add oslo.serialization

Add the new Oslo library for managing object serialization. This code is
moving out of the incubator into a library, so projects that wish to
continue using it need the requirement added to the global list first.

NOTE: this is needed for clients installed from master using oslo.serialization.

Conflicts:
	global-requirements.txt

Partial-Bug: #1366748

commit_message:
Stop using intersphinx

Remove intersphinx from the docs build as it triggers network calls that
occasionally fail, and we don't really use intersphinx (links other
sphinx documents out on the internet)

This also removes the requirement for internet access during docs build.

This causes docs jobs to fail because we error out on warnings.

Change-Id: I71e941e2a639641a662a163c682eb86d51de42fb
Related-Bug: #1368910

commit_message:
VolumeMultiBackendTest: delete error volumes

Record the volume ID before waiting for the volume status to go
available. This means that if the volume goes into error the tearDown
method can remove the volume.

Change-Id: I67e74af999862fc37c4f5b2474b50b62cce328e9
Partial-Bug: #1352498

commit_message:
Add update feature description to Fuel CLI docs

Since Fuel 5.1 there's an OpenStack patching feature, so we need to
describe how to run updating process using Fuel CLI.

Change-Id: I6be656f34107d284679b133d9995c26da1a7a9cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/28/120428/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To update some environment to newer OpenStack release (available since Fuel 5.1): :: fuel env update --env 1 --rel 42 In order to run rollback of failed updating, just change release id in the command above.

commit_message:
Document how to add/replace controller node

All in operations guide
- Modified 2320 to introduce subject and source other files
- redeploy subdirectory includes separate files for the actions
- Added steps to add/remove controller nodes

Closes-Bug: 1354586

Change-Id: Ic295b8848c297c2604cdae10d216315b75bdd097
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/57/110757/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _redeploy-node-ops: Adding, Redeploying, and Replacing Nodes ======================================== This section discusses how to add, redeploy, and replace :ref:`nodes<node-term>` in your OpenStack environment. Compute and Storage nodes have always been expandable; Controller nodes could not be added or replaced before Mirantis OpenStack 5.0.1. .. include:: /pages/operations/redeploy/1000-redeploy.rst .. include:: /pages/operations/redeploy/2000-add-compute-storage.rst .. include:: /pages/operations/redeploy/3000-add-controller.rst .. include:: /pages/operations/redeploy/4000-remove-controller.rst
deleted_lines: .. index:: HowTo: Redeploy a node from scratch .. _Redeploy_node_from_scratch: HowTo: Redeploy a node from scratch ------------------------------------ Compute and Storage nodes can be redeployed in environments that use HA and environments that do not. Note that Controller nodes cannot be redeployed without completely redeploying the environment. To deploy a Compute or Storage node, follow these steps: 1. Remove the node from your environment in the Fuel UI 2. Deploy Changes 3. Wait for the host to become available as an unallocated node 4. Add the node to the environment with the same role as before 5. Deploy Changes

commit_message:
state the fact that NSX Service node is mandatory for Mirantis OpenStack

- NSX cluster can successfully operate without Service node, but our
  tests show that creation of virtual interfaces fails, due to incorrect
  configuration of `replication_mode' setting in Neutron NSX plugin
  confguration file (plugin is configured to use Service node)
- we need more work to be done to implement working Mirantis OpenStack
  with NSX cluster that operates without Service node
- note that OpenStack itself can be used with NSX cluster that lacks
  Service node
- while here add missing article

Change-Id: Ibd88834a525104f4c9e71c355c3e7e0ea833adba
Closes-bug: #1365043
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/31/119331/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Install NSX Service node VMware NSX documentation states that NSX cluster can operate successfully without NSX Service node, but its presence is mandatory for deploying Mirantis OpenStack with NSX.* Configure NSX Service node

commit_message:
Adds "alarm-history" to test_telemetry_alarming_api

This submission is to verify alarm-history functionality
and also added required supporting function in
telemetry_client_base.py script.

Change-Id: Iadf9b6a10e908021d0cb0797d22ccc3775d472b2
Implements: bp add-basic-ceilometer-tests
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/57/92557/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @attr(type="smoke") def test_alarm_history(self): expectd_hstry = ['creation', 'deletion'] actual_hstry = list() alarm_name = data_utils.rand_name('telemetry_alarm') _, alarm = self.telemetry_client.create_alarm(name=alarm_name, type='threshold', threshold_rule=self.rule) self.telemetry_client.delete_alarm(alarm['alarm_id']) # Get alarm history and verify resp, history = self.telemetry_client.get_alarm_history( alarm['alarm_id']) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) actual_hstry = [h['type'] for h in history] missing_history = [h for h in expectd_hstry if h not in actual_hstry] self.assertEqual(0, len(missing_history), "Failed to find the following alarm history" " in actual history: %s" % ', '.join(str(h) for h in missing_history))

commit_message:
Fix selection of vsphere as non default backend

When vsphere is not the default backend, selecting
a specific backend over the documented "--store vsphere"
option does not work, since there is a class name check
that checks for vmware_datastore (as that is the name
of the class). However that class only handles the scheme
vmware_datastore. Add an alias hack similar to how
filesystem is handled.

Change-Id: Ifa2922b19f50b978e4ed1a2bf21663163ef8c58d
Fixes-Bug: #1354261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/54/112754/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
ResourceGroup build from list of resource names

This changes ResourceGroup internal implementation to be driven by
a list of resource names rather than a count of resources.

This maintains the current behaviour of sequential number resource
names, while allowing subclasses to choose a completely different
resource name scheme.

Change-Id: I17d046155f8d830ced789ede6a969ac4f125576d
Partial-Blueprint: deployment-multiple-servers

Use "incubated" doc theme

With Ib5a06ac1749fec475d326afe19f16fffb8c7d4a7 merging to oslosphinx,
we should now use the "incubated" doc theme. This patch enables it.

subject: Reactivating materialized theory tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-05 23:14:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/caf79783224c4f20e363cba89ca9eb958ab8024f', 'message': "WIP: Reactivating materialized theory tests

One of the features we mothballed before the alpha was
the option to use a theory that explicitly stores the contents
of all tables that are defined via rules.

This change begins reactivating that option
by reactivating the code's tests.

This is a WIP mainly because there's a bug in the theory when
rules get inserted/deleted.  If rules are inserted/deleted
in the same chunk of events that some of the dependent data
is updated, we do not get the right answer.  The reason is
that we are computing the collection of data generated
by the rule when that rule is enqueued, but that event
happens before the queue is processed.  Example..

insert[q(1)]
insert[p(x) :- q(x)].
enqueue[q(1)]
compute-consequences[p(x) :- q(x)] = {}
enqueue[p(x) :- q(x)]
enqueue[{}]
process[q(1)] <- when q(1) actually gets inserted
process[p(x) :- q(x)] <- just inserts rule

Clearly we need to do the data computation at the processing
step instead of at the enqueueing step.

Change-Id: I6f9ee25050d6c6cd42e176335d83b6fb7ac2821d

commit_message:
Reactivating materialized theory tests

One of the features we mothballed before the alpha was
the option to use a theory that explicitly stores the contents
of all tables that are defined via rules.

This change begins reactivating that option
by reactivating the code's tests.

Change-Id: I6f9ee25050d6c6cd42e176335d83b6fb7ac2821d

self.insert with 1 propagation") self.delete(run, ['r', 1.2]) self.check_class(run, 'p(1.2)', "String delete with 1 propagation") # def test_proofs(self): # """Test if the proof computation is performed correctly. """ # def check_table_proofs(run, table, tuple_proof_dict, msg): # for tuple in tuple_proof_dict: # tuple_proof_dict[tuple] = \ # Database.ProofCollection(tuple_proof_dict[tuple]) # self.check_proofs(run, {table : tuple_proof_dict}, msg) # code = ("q(x) :- p(x,y)") # run = self.prep_runtime(code, "**** Proof tests ****") # self.insert(run, ['p', 1, 2]) # check_table_proofs(run, 'q', {(1,): [{u'x': 1, u'y': 2}]}, # 'Simplest proof test') def test_materialized_negation(self): """Test Materialized Theory negation.""" # Unary, single join code = ("q(x) :- p(x), not r(x)") run = self.prep_runtime(code, "**** Materialized Theory: Negation ****") self.insert(run, ['p', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'p(2) q(2)', "Insert into positive literal with propagation") self.delete(run, ['p', 2]) self.check_class(run, '', "Delete from positive literal with propagation") self.insert(run, ['r', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'r(2)', "Insert into negative literal without propagation") self.delete(run, ['r', 2]) self.check_class(run, '', "Delete from negative literal without propagation") self.insert(run, ['p', 2]) self.insert(run, ['r', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'p(2) r(2)', "Insert into negative literal with propagation") self.delete(run, ['r', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'q(2) p(2)', "Delete from negative literal with propagation") # Unary, multiple joins code = ("s(x) :- p(x), not r(x), q(y), not t(y)") run = self.prep_runtime(code, "Unary, multiple join") self.insert(run, ['p', 1]) self.insert(run, ['q', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'p(1) q(2) s(1)', 'Insert with two negative literals') self.insert(run, ['r', 3]) self.check_class(run, 'p(1) q(2) s(1) r(3)', 'Ineffectual insert with 2 negative literals') self.insert(run, ['r', 1]) self.check_class( run, 'p(1) q(2) r(3) r(1)', 'Insert into existentially quantified negative literal ' 'with propagation. ') self.insert(run, ['t', 2]) self.check_class( run, 'p(1) q(2) r(3) r(1) t(2)', 'Insert into negative literal producing extra blocker for proof.') self.delete(run, ['t', 2]) self.check_class(run, 'p(1) q(2) r(3) r(1)', 'Delete first blocker from proof') self.delete(run, ['r', 1]) self.check_class(run, 'p(1) q(2) r(3) s(1)', 'Delete second blocker from proof') # Non-unary code = ("p(x, v) :- q(x,z), r(z, w), not s(x, w), u(w,v)") run = self.prep_runtime(code, "Non-unary") self.insert(run, ['q', 1, 2]) self.insert(run, ['r', 2, 3]) self.insert(run, ['r', 2, 4]) self.insert(run, ['u', 3, 5]) self.insert(run, ['u', 4, 6]) self.check_class( run, 'q(1,2) r(2,3) r(2,4) u(3,5) u(4,6) p(1,5) p(1,6)', 'Insert with non-unary negative literal') self.insert(run, ['s', 1, 3]) self.check_class( run, 'q(1,2) r(2,3) r(2,4) u(3,5) u(4,6) s(1,3) p(1,6)', 'Insert into non-unary negative with propagation') self.insert(run, ['s', 1, 4]) self.check_class( run, 'q(1,2) r(2,3) r(2,4) u(3,5) u(4,6) s(1,3) s(1,4)', 'Insert into non-unary with different propagation') # Negation ordering code = ("p(x) :- not q(x), r(x)") run = self.prep_runtime(code, "Negation ordering") self.insert(run, ['r', 1]) self.insert(run, ['r', 2]) self.insert(run, ['q', 1]) self.check_class( run, 'r(1) r(2) q(1) p(2)', 'Reordering negation') def test_materialized_select(self): """Materialized Theory: test the SELECT event handler.""" code = ("p(x, y) :- q(x), r(y)") run = self.prep_runtime(code, "**** Materialized Theory: Select ****") self.insert(run, ['q', 1]) # self.assertEqual('q(1)', run.select('q(x)')) self.insert(run, ['q', 2]) self.insert(run, ['r', 1]) self.insert(run, ['r', 2]) self.check_class( run, 'q(1) q(2) r(1) r(2) p(1,1) p(1,2) p(2,1) p(2,2)', 'Prepare for select') self.check_equal( run.select('p(x,y)'), 'p(1,1) p(1,2) p(2,1) p(2,2)', 'Select: bound no args') self.check_equal( run.select('p(1,y)'), 'p(1,1) p(1,2)', 'Select: bound 1st arg') self.check_equal( run.select('p(x,2)'), 'p(1,2) p(2,2)', 'Select: bound 2nd arg') self.check_equal( run.select('p(1,2)'), 'p(1,2)', 'Select: bound 1st and 2nd arg') self.check_equal( run.select('query :- q(x), r(y)'), 'query :- q(1), r(1)' 'query :- q(1), r(2)' 'query :- q(2), r(1)' 'query :- q(2), r(2)') def test_materialized_modify_rules(self): """Materialized Theory: Test the functionality for adding and deleting rules *after* data has already been entered. """ run = self.prep_runtime("", "Rule modification") run.insert("q(1) r(1) q(2) r(2)") self.showdb(run) self.check_class(run, 'q(1) r(1) q(2) r(2)', "Installation") run.insert("p(x) :- q(x), r(x)") self.check_class( run, 'q(1) r(1) q(2) r(2) p(1) p(2)', 'Rule insert after data insert') run.delete("q(1)") self.check_class( run, 'r(1) q(2) r(2) p(2)', 'Delete after Rule insert with propagation') run.insert("q(1)") run.delete("p(x) :- q(x), r(x)") self.check_class(run, 'q(1) r(1) q(2) r(2)', "Delete rule") def test_materialized_recursion(self): """Materialized Theory: test recursion.""" run = self.prep_runtime('q(x,y) :- p(x,y)' 'q(x,y) :- p(x,z), q(z,y)') run.insert('p(1,2)') run.insert('p(2,3)') run.insert('p(3,4)') run.insert('p(4,5)') self.check_class( run, 'p(1,2) p(2,3) p(3,4) p(4,5)' 'q(1,2) q(2,3) q(1,3) q(3,4) q(2,4) q(1,4) q(4,5) q(3,5) ' 'q(1,5) q(2,5)', 'Insert into recursive rules') run.delete('p(1,2)') self.check_class( run, 'p(2,3) p(3,4) p(4,5)' 'q(2,3) q(3,4) q(2,4) q(4,5) q(3,5) q(2,5)', 'Delete from recursive rules') def open(self, msg): LOG.debug("** Started: {} **".format(msg)) def close(self, msg): LOG.debug("** Finished: {} **".format(msg)) # TODO(tim): add tests for explanations def test_materialized_explain(self): """Test the explanation event handler.""" run = self.prep_runtime("p(x) :- q(x), r(x)", "Explanations") run.insert("q(1) r(1)") self.showdb(run) LOG.debug(run.explain("p(1)")) run = self.prep_runtime( "p(x) :- q(x), r(x) q(x) :- s(x), t(x)", "Explanations") run.insert("s(1) r(1) t(1)") self.showdb(run) LOG.debug(run.explain("p(1)")) # self.fail()

commit_message:
Resurrected more policy tests

Before the alpha release, we mothballed a number of policy tests and features.
We thought we had saved all the tests for features that were
actually included in the alpha, but we missed some.

This change reactivates those tests.

Change-Id: I42f3ea01d8cb07204321d229de864db43f492c66

commit_message:
Enable filtering of services by name

This commit enables the filtering of services through the service's
name. This wasn't available before, since the name is not saved in the
backend as a column, but instead it's stored as an extra attribute.

Thus, this commits enables this type of search by asserting a TODO that
was left in the SQL backend, and also adding the `name` attribute to the
filterprotected decorator.

This is needed since some clients (namely python-openstackclient) assume
that this functionality already exists and thus give the option to
create endpoints with the service name as a parameter.

Change-Id: Ifc9c1e44e908410740f6f20380b264d35096fcac
Closes-Bug: #1350273

added_lines: @validation.add_validator(validation.image_exists("image_id")) def boot_custom_runcommand_server(self, image_id, flavor_parameters, script, interpreter, network='private', username='ubuntu', ip_version=4, retries=60, port=22, **kwargs): """Boot server and run a script that outputs JSON. Parameters: script: script to run on the server, must output JSON mapping metric names to values. See sample script below. network: Network to choose address to connect to instance from username: User to SSH to instance as ip_version: Version of ip protocol to use for connection returns: Dictionary containing two keys, data and errors. Data is JSON data output by the script. Errors is raw data from the script's standard error stream. Example Script in doc/samples/support/instance_dd_test.sh """ flavor_name = self._generate_random_name(16) flavor_id = self._create_custom_flavor(self, flavor_name=flavor_name, vcpu_count=flavor_parameters['vcpu'], ram_size=flavor_parameters['ram'], hdd_size=flavor_parameters['hdd']) server_name = self._generate_random_name(16) server = self._boot_server(server_name, image_id, flavor_id, key_name='rally_ssh_key', **kwargs) if network not in server.addresses: raise ValueError( "Can't find cloud network %(network)s, so cannot boot " "instance for Rally scenario boot-runcommand-delete. " "Available networks: %(networks)s" % ( dict(network=network, networks=server.addresses.keys() ) ) ) server_ip = [ip for ip in server.addresses[network] if ip['version'] == ip_version][0]['addr'] ssh = sshutils.SSH(username, server_ip, port=port, pkey=self.clients('ssh_key_pair')['private']) ssh.wait() code, out, err = ssh.execute(interpreter, stdin=open(script, 'rb')) if code: LOG.error(_('Error running script on instance via SSH. ' 'Error: %s') % err) try: out = json.loads(out) except ValueError: LOG.warning(_('Script %s did not output valid JSON. ') % script) LOG.debug(_('Output streams from in-instance script execution: ' 'stdout: %(stdout)s, stderr: $(stderr)s') % dict( stdout=out, stderr=err)) return {'data': out, 'errors': err}

commit_message:
Make generate_password more secure

It appears that the generate_password function in
cinder/volume/utils.py was based on a function from
nova/utils.py .  The version in Nova has been updated
to use random.SystemRandom() to get better random
passwords.

This change brings those changes into Cinder.

NOTE: In the future we should look at getting this function
      moved to Oslo as it is being used in Cinder and Nova.

Change-Id: I3ea4fffbcbf22d7e0de4874dcfb592ecf523b4cc
Closes-bug: 1368040
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/93/121193/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add merge_stderr option to all client methods

This commit makes the client methods behave more uniformly. Before
there only certain methods had a kwarg for merge_stderr, which could
lead to unexpected behavior depending on the clients being used. By
adding the option everywhere there shouldn't be an unexpected behavior
around merge_stderr.

Change-Id: I227d5e684c94da29a47eb9876a9ed40cdbea084c

commit_message:
Fix the filename copy into the filename input

In horizon/static/horizon/js/horizon.form.js,
edited the function handle_object_upload_source.

As the form validation is done by Angular,
the filename change has to be done by Angular (done).
The filename input has to be filled if it has been emptied
(added a condition in the if statement).

Now, when you choose a file, its filename in copied into the filename input
each time you choose a new file and until you manually
change the filename input content.

Change-Id: Ibbebc7ecf2902486db24f50ba12d20facf258581
Closes-Bug: 1364295
Co-Authored-By: Maxime Vidori <maxime.vidori@enovance.com>

subject: Fixed bug for inserting rules via API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-10 19:42:55.000000000', 'files': ['congress/api/error_codes.py', 'congress/api/rule_model.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/babbb470f12ab7cb7def4a5a8ab768d1ba37188e', 'message': 'Fixed bug for inserting rules via API

Previously, if you inserted multiple rules in a single string
via the API, we did not catch the error.  Instead, we simply
processed the first rule.  One symptom of this problem
is an internal server error when someone uses a minus sign
in the middle of a table name, e.g. router-name(x) :- ...
Because of the grammar, this rule would be parsed as two
separate rules: router-() and name(x) :- ...

This change checks that the number of rules sent into
the API is always 1 and shows you the list of rules that
you submitted in the error message.  This helps the user
debug the problem.

Perhaps the grammar should be changed as well, but this
fix is necessary in either case.

Closes-bug: 1367887
Change-Id: I7efec72ef96d6958c1af227d3ef8fb0707703f3b
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed bug for inserting rules via API

Previously, if you inserted multiple rules in a single string
via the API, we did not catch the error.  Instead, we simply
processed the first rule.  One symptom of this problem
is an internal server error when someone uses a minus sign
in the middle of a table name, e.g. router-name(x) :- ...
Because of the grammar, this rule would be parsed as two
separate rules: router-() and name(x) :- ...

This change checks that the number of rules sent into
the API is always 1 and shows you the list of rules that
you submitted in the error message.  This helps the user
debug the problem.

Perhaps the grammar should be changed as well, but this
fix is necessary in either case.

Closes-bug: 1367887
Change-Id: I7efec72ef96d6958c1af227d3ef8fb0707703f3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/64/120564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Updating JobBinaries to use proxy for Swift access

Changes
* refactoring get_raw_binary to accept proxy configs
* refactoring get_raw_data to use proxy Swift connection when necessary
* adding function to get a Swift Connection object from proxy user
* refactoring upload_job_files_to_hdfs and upload_job_files to use proxy
  user when necessary
* changing JobBinary JSON schema to allow blank username/password if
  proxy domains are being used
* adding function to get the Swift public endpoint for the current
  project
* adding test for JobBinary creation without credentials

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication
Change-Id: I02e76016194fbbb62b8ab7b304eecc53d580a79c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/52/117052/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_raw_binary(job_binary, proxy_configs=None): res = i_swift.get_raw_data(context.ctx(), job_binary, proxy_configs)

commit_message:
Compute v2 api server status value cleanup

Server status need to be updated to reflect current standards.
Adding statuses like STOPPED, PAUSED, SOFT_DELETED and updating
old values to new ones like RESCUED, RESIZED, DELETED.

Change-Id: I77b06331f4f23abdbc02bed7f2be21aaff6a2091
Closes-Bug: #1362845
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/26/121226/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BUILDING. The server has not finished the original build DELETED. The server is permanently deleted. PAUSED. In a paused state, the state of the server is stored in RAM. A paused server continues to run in frozen state. RESCUED. The server is in rescue mode. A rescue image is running with the original server image attached. RESIZED. Server is performing the differential copy of data SOFT_DELETED. The server is marked as deleted but the disk images are still available to restore. STOPPED. The server is powered off and the disk image still persists.
deleted_lines: BUILD. The server has not finished the original build DELETED. The server is deleted. RESCUE. The server is in rescue mode. RESIZE. Server is performing the differential copy of data

commit_message:
labs: split out process_begin_files

Move the processing of *.begin status files into a separate function.
Call that function only if the host's status directory is shared with
the client scripts (through VirtualBox guest-additions).

Change-Id: I7716528c02aa4f8b5fc0901ff91ba5d37b5a0d9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/72/120772/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function process_begin_files { local processing=("$STATUS_DIR"/*.sh.begin) if [ -n "${processing[0]-}" ]; then local file for file in "${processing[@]}"; do echo >&2 -en "\nVM processing $(basename "$file" .begin)" rm "$file" done fi } ${WBATCH:-:} process_begin_files
deleted_lines: local processing=("$STATUS_DIR"/*.sh.begin) if [ -n "${processing[0]-}" ]; then for f in "${processing[@]}"; do echo >&2 -en "\nVM processing $(basename "$f" .begin)" rm "$f" done fi

commit_message:
For dse to use eventlets rather than threads

This spec proposes a change to Congress and the DSE to make
the DSE use greenthreads rather than regular threads.

Change-Id: If2ea9a54982c602e60dfda0cfc0852224846e876
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/72/116972/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Convert the DSE from using threads to using eventless ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/dse Currently, the OpenStack standards are to use eventlets over threads. The DSE framework was merged into Congress using threads and needs to be changed to use eventlets to be more in line with the OpenStack standards. Problem description =================== The DSE currently uses threads for each of the services it loads, while the rest of OpenStack uses eventlets over threads. Eventlets can scale better than threads and are able to be stopped, while threads cannot be stopped with a single method. This raises a problem because if there is a limit to the amount of threads that can be run without causing performance issues. Proposed change =============== The change that I propose is to make the deepSix class inherit from greenlet.greenlet (from the eventlet python module) rather than inheriting from threading.Thread. This will make each service a greenlet rather than a thread. Also, when the DSE creates the services in the create service method, it will spawn them as greenlets, rather than start threads. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The loading and starting of a d6service will change. Old way (taken from test_dse.py lines 31-35): cage = congress.dse.d6cage.d6cage() # so that we exit once test finishes; all other threads are forced # to be daemons cage.setDaemon(True) cage.start() New way: cage = congress.dse.d6cage.d6cage() cage.start() Performance Impact ------------------ This code will be called every time a d6service object is created. The implemented code should not have any effects on performance since it is executed as quickly as threading is. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: harrison.kelly (email: harrison.kelly@plexxi.com) Work Items ---------- Change d6cage.py to run each service as a greenlet instead of a thread. Change deepsix.py to inherit from greenlet.greenlet instead of threading.Thread and spawn eventlets instead of threads. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tests with DSE modules will be used to check if implementation does not effect the capabilities of the DSE. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Update scripts to initialize heat domain

Updates devtest_{seed,undercloud,overcloud} to use Heat's tool for
creating a stack user domain in Keystone.

Updates the passwords scripts and passwords rc files as well to account
for the additional password.

This depends on If4b4266ce66212d7ae2579e7da6d3bae779ad04a landing in
Heat.

Partial-Bug: #1287453
Change-Id: I5ff23caab9f87baf96007b61b3bd604694f44301
Co-Authored-By: Clint Byrum <clint@fewbar.com>

commit_message:
Ironic:  Fix direct use of flavor and instance module objects

This replaces all uses of nova.objects.flavor_obj.Flavor* with
nova.objects.Flavor* and nova.objects.instance_obj.Instance* with
nova.objects.Instance*

This work was done throughout Nova. An example of this is
commit 3c1085f528596089a638ac3bb44a9ed3e201e62f.

Change-Id: I8f2dbb408acbdf8124bc141925de03ce6f12bd91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/119707/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import objects flavor = objects.Flavor.get_by_id(context, instance['instance_type_id']) return [objects.Instance.get_by_uuid(context, i.instance_uuid).name flavor = objects.Flavor.get_by_id(context, instance['instance_type_id'])
deleted_lines: from nova.objects import flavor as flavor_obj from nova.objects import instance as instance_obj flavor = flavor_obj.Flavor.get_by_id(context, instance['instance_type_id']) return [instance_obj.Instance.get_by_uuid(context, i.instance_uuid).name flavor = flavor_obj.Flavor.get_by_id(context, instance['instance_type_id'])

commit_message:
Add heat-keystone-setup-domain to sphinx conf.py

The man page for heat-keystone-setup-domain was not being generated
because it was not included in the sphinx conf.py.

Change-Id: Ic1c2025fc7f61e3c37906b42bd84e1df893920fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/26/120426/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ('man/heat-keystone-setup-domain', 'heat-keystone-setup-domain', u'Script which sets up a keystone domain for heat users and projects', [u'Heat Developers'], 1),

subject: Stop stack tracing when trying to auto-stop a stopped instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-18 13:58:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8ef0303c8accf97def935b03e9fff134339d2e3c', 'message': 'WIP: synchronize handle_lifecycle_event to avoid stop race error

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

That change missed the call to _sync_instance_power_state in
handle_lifecycle_event which is also detecting power state changes via
events and automatically stopping the instance, which also races with
stop_instance, so this change adds the lock to handle_lifecycle_event
also.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-18 17:39:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ea1fdab2aeac1188d3e9e615ae607c25796694e4', 'message': 'WIP: synchronize handle_lifecycle_event to avoid stop race error

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

That change missed the call to _sync_instance_power_state in
handle_lifecycle_event which is also detecting power state changes via
events and automatically stopping the instance, which also races with
stop_instance, so this change adds the lock to handle_lifecycle_event
also.

Adds debug logging to handle_lifecycle_event and stop_instance to
dump the current instance state after acquiring the lock.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-07-25 19:00:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/865c34fdbb2c884a658b3e090c4f23527021c134', 'message': "WIP: synchronize handle_lifecycle_event to avoid stop race error

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

That change missed the call to _sync_instance_power_state in
handle_lifecycle_event which is also detecting power state changes via
events and automatically stopping the instance, which also races with
stop_instance, so this change adds the lock to handle_lifecycle_event
also.

Adds debug logging to handle_lifecycle_event and stop_instance to
dump the current instance state after acquiring the lock.

Also adds a check for UnexpectedTaskStateError when the sync instance
power state method calls compute_api.force_stop since it's an
asynchronous call so we can still get that error, but it shouldn't
stacktrace since the sync method should basically ignore anything
going through a task state change.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad

"}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-07-30 06:20:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7b791745c1c2d89a3864264593c17b028cb19f81', 'message': "Stop stack tracing when trying to auto-stop a stopped instance

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

The handle_lifecycle_event method is getting callbacks from the libvirt
driver on state changes on the VM and calling the
_sync_instance_power_state method which may try to stop the instance
asynchronously, and lead to UnexpectedTaskStateError if the instance is
already stopped by the time it gets the lock and the task_state has
changed.

Attempting to lock in handle_lifecycle_event just moves the race around
so this change adds logic to stop_instance such that if the instance
says it's active but the virt driver says it's not running, then we add
None to the expected_task_state so we don't stacktrace on
instance.save().

An alternative and/or additional change to this would be doing a call
rather than a cast when _sync_instance_power_state calls the stop API
but in some previous testing it doesn't appear to make a significant
difference in the race found when we hit the stop_instance method.

Adds a bunch of debug logging since this code is inherently racey and
is needed when looking at failures around these operations.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad

is needed when looking at failures around these operations.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

The handle_lifecycle_event method is getting callbacks from the libvirt
driver on state changes on the VM and calling the
_sync_instance_power_state method which may try to stop the instance
asynchronously, and lead to UnexpectedTaskStateError if the instance is
already stopped by the time it gets the lock and the task_state has
changed.

Attempting to lock in handle_lifecycle_event just moves the race around
so this change adds logic to stop_instance such that if the instance
says it's active but the virt driver says it's not running, then we add
None to the expected_task_state so we don't stacktrace on
instance.save().

An alternative and/or additional change to this would be doing a call
rather than a cast when _sync_instance_power_state calls the stop API
but in some previous testing it doesn't appear to make a significant
difference in the race found when we hit the stop_instance method.

Adds a bunch of debug logging since this code is inherently racey and
is needed when looking at failures around these operations.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad

commit_message:
Stop stack tracing when trying to auto-stop a stopped instance

Commit cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 added locks to
stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task to try and fix a
race between stopping the instance via the API where the task_state is
set to powering-off, and the periodic task seeing the instance
power_state as shutdown in _sync_instance_power_state and calling the
stop API again, at which point the task_state is already None from the
first stop API call and we get an UnexpectedTaskStateError.

The handle_lifecycle_event method is getting callbacks from the libvirt
driver on state changes on the VM and calling the
_sync_instance_power_state method which may try to stop the instance
asynchronously, and lead to UnexpectedTaskStateError if the instance is
already stopped by the time it gets the lock and the task_state has
changed.

Attempting to lock in handle_lifecycle_event just moves the race around
so this change adds logic to stop_instance such that if the instance
says it's active but the virt driver says it's not running, then we add
None to the expected_task_state so we don't stacktrace on
instance.save().

An alternative and/or additional change to this would be doing a call
rather than a cast when _sync_instance_power_state calls the stop API
but in some previous testing it doesn't appear to make a significant
difference in the race found when we hit the stop_instance method.

Adds a bunch of debug logging since this code is inherently racey and
is needed when looking at failures around these operations.

Closes-Bug: #1339235
Closes-Bug: #1266611
Related-Bug: #1320628

Change-Id: Ib495a5ab15de88051c5fa7abfb58a5445691dcad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/108014/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): We synchronize to avoid raises with # stop_instance and the _sync_power_states periodic task. @utils.synchronized(instance.uuid) def do_handle_lifecycle_event(): self._sync_instance_power_state(context, instance, vm_power_state) do_handle_lifecycle_event()# # NOTE(mriedem): We expect 'powering-off' because the compute API # # sets that task state, but we also expect None because the # # _sync_power_states periodic task can set that if we don't hit # # the lock at the right time. # instance.save(expected_task_state=(task_states.POWERING_OFF, # None))

commit_message:
switch to sqlalchemy core

ORM has an overhead associated with it. we need fast writes so
switch to use sqlalchemy core to improve performance.

Closes-Bug: #1356000
Change-Id: I45c76d4f294f9bdb6d0f04e94d4be7e0f7ca6f2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/24/113524/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

name, meter.c.type == type, meter.c.unit == unit))).scalar() if meter_id is None: conn.execute(meter.insert(), name=name, type=type, unit=unit) meter_id = conn.execute( sa.select([meter.c.id]) .where(sa.and_(meter.c.name == name, meter.c.type == type, meter.c.unit == unit))).scalar() meter_id = Connection._create_meter(conn, name, type, unit) return meter_id def _create_resource(conn, res_id, user_id, project_id, source_id, res = models.Resource.__table__ m_hash = hashlib.md5(jsonutils.dumps(rmeta)).hexdigest() internal_id = conn.execute( sa.select([res.c.internal_id]) .where(sa.and_(res.c.resource_id == res_id, res.c.user_id == user_id, res.c.project_id == project_id, res.c.source_id == source_id, res.c.metadata_hash == m_hash))).scalar() if internal_id is None: conn.execute(res.insert(), resource_id=res_id, user_id=user_id, project_id=project_id, source_id=source_id, resource_metadata=rmeta, metadata_hash=m_hash) internal_id = conn.execute( sa.select([res.c.internal_id]) .where(sa.and_(res.c.resource_id == res_id, res.c.user_id == user_id, res.c.project_id == project_id, res.c.source_id == source_id, res.c.metadata_hash == m_hash))).scalar() new_res = True internal_id = Connection._create_resource(conn, res_id, user_id, project_id, source_id, rmeta) return internal_id, new_res start = timeutils.utcnow() with self._engine_facade.get_engine().begin() as conn: m_id = self._create_meter(conn, data['counter_name'], data['counter_type'], data['counter_unit']) res_id, new_res = self._create_resource(conn, data['resource_id'], data['user_id'], data['project_id'], data['source'], rmetadata) sample = models.Sample.__table__ conn.execute(sample.insert(), meter_id=m_id, resource_id=res_id, timestamp=data['timestamp'], volume=data['counter_volume'], message_signature=data['message_signature'], message_id=data['message_id']) conn.execute(_model.__table__.insert(), id=res_id, meta_key=key, value=v) total = timeutils.utcnow() - start LOG.error('TIME TO DB: %s' % total)

commit_message:
Add use of nova_kwargs for nova servers create to improve readability

so if we have to add new args to the servers.create call,
we'll be able to use nova_kwargs and avoid mulitple calls
of servers.create with multiple if conditions.

Closes-Bug: 1368109
Change-Id: Ib2e435846d3f3d6907c4959ba31abf003c3b47d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/51/119051/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('availability_zone', help='Specify the AZ where your cluster will be deployed.') ] CONF.register_opts(opts) kwargs = {'scheduler_hints': hints, 'userdata': userdata, 'key_name': cluster.user_keypair_id, 'security_groups': node_group.security_groups} kwargs['nics'] = [{"net-id": net_id, "v4-fixed-ip": ""}] if CONF.availability_zone: kwargs['availability_zone'] = CONF.availability_zone nova_instance = nova.client().servers.create(name, node_group.get_image_id(), node_group.flavor_id, **kwargs)
deleted_lines: nics = [{"net-id": net_id, "v4-fixed-ip": ""}] nova_instance = nova.client().servers.create( name, node_group.get_image_id(), node_group.flavor_id, scheduler_hints=hints, userdata=userdata, key_name=cluster.user_keypair_id, nics=nics, security_groups=node_group.security_groups) else: nova_instance = nova.client().servers.create( name, node_group.get_image_id(), node_group.flavor_id, scheduler_hints=hints, userdata=userdata, key_name=cluster.user_keypair_id, security_groups=node_group.security_groups)

commit_message:
Fix password leak from ProcessExecution errors

This backport required changes to fix both issues:
* Make execute method clean password in exception
* Make sure mask_password works properly

This backport is not trivial as these fixes relies on many other
changes, only the necessary code have been imported/adapted.

------------------------------------------------
The sync pulls in the following changes (newest to oldest):

63c99a0f - Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages
66142c34 - Make strutils.mask_password more secure
d6b55fb2 - Remove `processutils` dependency on `log`
cb5a804b - Move `mask_password` to strutils

-----------------------------------------------

Closes-Bug: 1343604
Closes-Bug: 1345233
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I3b49b1d667f6ade9ae3f6765d735440a3e838917
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/81/120881/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(flaper87): The following globals are used by `mask_password` _SANITIZE_KEYS = ['adminPass', 'admin_pass', 'password', 'admin_password'] # NOTE(ldbragst): Let's build a list of regex objects using the list of # _SANITIZE_KEYS we already have. This way, we only have to add the new key # to the list of _SANITIZE_KEYS and we can generate regular expressions # for XML and JSON automatically. _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_2 = [] _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_1 = [] # NOTE(amrith): Some regular expressions have only one parameter, some # have two parameters. Use different lists of patterns here. _FORMAT_PATTERNS_1 = [r'(%(key)s\s*[=]\s*)[^\s^\'^\"]+'] _FORMAT_PATTERNS_2 = [r'(%(key)s\s*[=]\s*[\"\']).*?([\"\'])', r'(%(key)s\s+[\"\']).*?([\"\'])', r'([-]{2}%(key)s\s+)[^\'^\"^=^\s]+([\s]*)', r'(<%(key)s>).*?(</%(key)s>)', r'([\"\']%(key)s[\"\']\s*:\s*[\"\']).*?([\"\'])', r'([\'"].*?%(key)s[\'"]\s*:\s*u?[\'"]).*?([\'"])', r'([\'"].*?%(key)s[\'"]\s*,\s*\'--?[A-z]+\'\s*,\s*u?' '[\'"]).*?([\'"])', r'(%(key)s\s*--?[A-z]+\s*)\S+(\s*)'] for key in _SANITIZE_KEYS: for pattern in _FORMAT_PATTERNS_2: reg_ex = re.compile(pattern % {'key': key}, re.DOTALL) _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_2.append(reg_ex) for pattern in _FORMAT_PATTERNS_1: reg_ex = re.compile(pattern % {'key': key}, re.DOTALL) _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_1.append(reg_ex) def mask_password(message, secret="***"): """Replace password with 'secret' in message. :param message: The string which includes security information. :param secret: value with which to replace passwords. :returns: The unicode value of message with the password fields masked. For example: >>> mask_password("'adminPass' : 'aaaaa'") "'adminPass' : '***'" >>> mask_password("'admin_pass' : 'aaaaa'") "'admin_pass' : '***'" >>> mask_password('"password" : "aaaaa"') '"password" : "***"' >>> mask_password("'original_password' : 'aaaaa'") "'original_password' : '***'" >>> mask_password("u'original_password' : u'aaaaa'") "u'original_password' : u'***'" """ message = six.text_type(message) # NOTE(ldbragst): Check to see if anything in message contains any key # specified in _SANITIZE_KEYS, if not then just return the message since # we don't have to mask any passwords. if not any(key in message for key in _SANITIZE_KEYS): return message substitute = r'\g<1>' + secret + r'\g<2>' for pattern in _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_2: message = re.sub(pattern, substitute, message) substitute = r'\g<1>' + secret for pattern in _SANITIZE_PATTERNS_1: message = re.sub(pattern, substitute, message) return message

commit_message:
Support for setting boot mode in pxe_ilo driver

This commit adds support for setting boot mode in pxe_ilo
driver with the help of iloclient.
It modifies the PXEAndIloDriver so that it uses
IloPower for power management,
IloPXEDeploy for image deployment,
IloPXEVendorPassthru for vendorpassthru,
IPMITool console and management interfaces.

Change-Id: Ifb29c6b4c60ce17a7e5c15af7fb62e1c1e1c9ad7
Implements: blueprint uefi-boot-for-ironic
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/78/118578/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.drivers.modules.ilo import deploy as ilo_deploy self.deploy = ilo_deploy.IloPXEDeploy() self.console = ipmitool.IPMIShellinaboxConsole() self.management = ipmitool.IPMIManagement()

commit_message:
Add option for building Ironic deploy ramdisks

Does what it says.

Change-Id: If8e347155b0af9b4fe50f4277887e68f94c0915a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/73/119473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set to 0 to avoid building Ironic deploy ramdisks export DEVSTACK_GATE_IRONIC_BUILD_RAMDISKS=${DEVSTACK_GATE_IRONIC_BUILD_RAMDISKS:-1}

subject: Method for getting NUMA usage from an instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-18 11:43:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ee2cd1617c238814a3e226e069cc4a9be93649f6', 'message': 'Method for getting NUMA usage from an instance

At present, neither ResourceTracker nor HostManager use objects
consistently. Due to that - we need to handle numa_topology being both
a json blob, instance of VirtNUMATopology, or None at different places
in the code. In addition to that - it can either be a field in a dict,
a NovaObject attribute, or even an attribute on an object that does not
support .get() interface.

Poluting the VirtNUMAHostTopology.get_usage_from_instances breaks
separation of concerns, and is just poor design, but we do need to go
through the same logic in several places, so we add a convenience method
that knows how to deal with all the different combinations described
above.

Change-Id: I91c3a77153ef8e5e701d3bc7af37ff0a2943fc0c
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-19 19:20:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f7d29081793f6f52d4663c1367885fe43f8a37a9', 'message': 'Method for getting NUMA usage from an instance

Polluting the VirtNUMAHostTopology.get_usage_from_instances breaks
separation of concerns, and is just poor design, but we do need to go
through the same logic in several places, so we add a convenience method
that knows how to deal with all the different combinations described
above.

Change-Id: I91c3a77153ef8e5e701d3bc7af37ff0a2943fc0c
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

commit_message:
Method for getting NUMA usage from an instance

At present, neither ResourceTracker nor HostManager use objects
consistently. Due to that - we need to handle numa_topology being both
a json blob, instance of VirtNUMATopology, or None at different places
in the code. In addition to that - it can either be a field in a dict,
a NovaObject attribute, or even an attribute on an object that does not
support .get() interface.

Polluting the VirtNUMAHostTopology.get_usage_from_instances breaks
separation of concerns, and is just poor design, but we do need to go
through the same logic in several places, so we add a convenience method
that knows how to deal with all the different combinations described
above.

We also add a separated out method for getting the numa_topology out of
all the possible ways we use instance currently, as it will be useful
for filtering to know if the instance actually has a defined
numa_topology.

Change-Id: I91c3a77153ef8e5e701d3bc7af37ff0a2943fc0c
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/114938/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six def get_host_numa_usage_from_intance(host, instance, free=False, never_serialize_result=False): """Calculate new 'numa_usage' of 'host' from 'instance' NUMA usage This is a convenience method to help us handle the fact that we use several different types rhrouught the code (ComputeNode and Instance objects, dicts, scheduler HostState) which may have both json and deserialized versions of VirtNUMATopology classes. Handles all the complexity without poluting the class method with it. :param host: nova.objects.ComputeNode instance, or a db object or dict :param instance: nova.objects.Instance instance, or a db object or dict :param free: if True usage of the host will be decreased :param never_serialize_result: if True result will always be an instance of VirtNUMAHostTopology class. :returns: numa_usage in the format it was on the host or VirtNUMAHostTopology instance if never_serialize_result was True """ jsonify_result = False instance_numa_topology = instance.get('numa_topology') if instance_numa_topology: if isinstance(instance_numa_topology, six.string_types): instance_numa_topology = VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.from_json( instance_numa_topology) instance_numa_topology = [instance_numa_topology] try: host_numa_topology = host.get('numa_topology') except AttributeError: host_numa_topology = host.numa_topology if host_numa_topology is not None and isinstance( host_numa_topology, six.string_types): jsonify_result = True host_numa_topology = VirtNUMAHostTopology.from_json(host_numa_topology) updated_numa_topology = ( VirtNUMAHostTopology.usage_from_instances( host_numa_topology, instance_numa_topology, free=free)) if updated_numa_topology is not None: if jsonify_result and not never_serialize_result: updated_numa_topology = updated_numa_topology.to_json() return updated_numa_topology

commit_message:
Add oslo.serialization

Add the new Oslo library for managing object serialization. This code is
moving out of the incubator into a library, so projects that wish to
continue using it need the requirement added to the global list first.

NOTE: this is needed for clients installed from master using oslo.serialization.

Conflicts:
	global-requirements.txt

Partial-Bug: #1366748

Change-Id: Iff29ce2e88cddc2332229cfbbc518251dd2c76f3
(cherry picked from commit 2ce3f8259b56410bdd73deca09b7963f4a46e1da)

commit_message:
Remove the objectify decorator

The objectify decorator was used to convert DB objects into RPC objects,
but it's not being used anymore since out objects API already has
correspondent methods to match the dbapi ones.

Also, since dbapi methods didn't get a context the decorator was forming
bad RPC objects without a context stored within it.

Change-Id: I892ab6ee2236af040c7f8effcfdfecb293e13ab6
Partial-Bug: #1314732

deleted_lines: import functools def objectify(klass): """Decorator to convert database results into specified objects.""" def the_decorator(fn): @functools.wraps(fn) def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): result = fn(*args, **kwargs) try: return klass._from_db_object(klass(), result) except TypeError: # TODO(deva): handle lists of objects better # once support for those lands and is imported. return [klass._from_db_object(klass(), obj) for obj in result] return wrapper return the_decorator Port, objectify)

commit_message:
Use 'configure' instead of 'enable' when talking about kernel function configuration

Because we enable and disable kernel networking functions we should
use 'configure' instead of 'enable'.

Change-Id: Ia0aa260bfa49c076ab62fd3a161b986140c7912d

commit_message:
Call unbind_snat_servicenode from schedule router

Refactor to move the call to plugin.unbind_snat_servicenode from
schedule_snat_router to _schedule_router.  This is a move to pave the
way for removing hints from schedule router.

Partial-bug: #1353266
Partial-bug: #1356639
Co-Authored-By: Swaminathan Vasudevan <swaminathan.vasudevan@hp.com>

Change-Id: I062d8cc3cb870bbaa033d5b107a7dd868dfafa19

commit_message:
Refacfored a more suitable ovs_redhat provider

  - Added a helper class/library to handle ifcfg content

  - Removed keep_ip and sleep parameters, replaced by
    automatic behaviour

  - No need for a redhat vs_bridge provider

  - Only port/bridge associated with a phyical interface get a
    ifcfg file managed

  - Requires Puppet 2.7.8+
    Not using optional_commands anymore

When the bridge is associated with an active physical interface
  - It will be initially populated from the existing interface
    file, inheriting its parameters

Change-Id: I584fb1442de9a760b3a092f96cbfcbcd6776fdba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-vswitch refs/changes/04/94504/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: newparam(:keep_ip) do desc "True: keep physical interface's details and assign them to the bridge" defaultto false end newparam(:sleep) do desc "Waiting time, in seconds (0 by default), for network to sync after activating port, used with keep_ip only" defaultto '0' validate do |value| if value.to_i.class != Fixnum || value.to_i < 0 raise ArgumentError, "sleep requires a positive integer" end end end

commit_message:
Catch NotImplementedError on reset_network for xen

This patch adds a @messaging.expected_exceptions(NotImplementedError)
decorator around reset_network as xen raises NotImplementedError here.

Change-Id: Ib1a0cb400ea89f387cd43630d8c647bf5c99f7ab
Closes-bug: #1306404
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/86812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @messaging.expected_exceptions(NotImplementedError)

commit_message:
Remove templates from toctrees

We don't want the templates to show up in the RSS feed, so exclude them
from being converted to HTML and listed in the toctree.

Change-Id: I8e72a938e007b891720138eb127268a5f950872c
