commit_message:
Expose auth methods on the adapter

Provide access to get_token, get_endpoint and invalidate to the adapter.
The adapter is essentially created per individual client and it can be
useful to know things like the endpoint that requests will be sent to
based on the parameters that are included in the endpoint_filter.

This essentially allows us to emulate the management_url and auth_token
properties of the existing clients.

Change-Id: Ic01bc52bb38e8fb72e7a6d93bfd2944b11d0b070
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/09/117709/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _set_endpoint_filter_kwargs(self, kwargs): if self.service_type: kwargs.setdefault('service_type', self.service_type) if self.service_name: kwargs.setdefault('service_name', self.service_name) if self.interface: kwargs.setdefault('interface', self.interface) if self.region_name: kwargs.setdefault('region_name', self.region_name) if self.version: kwargs.setdefault('version', self.version) self._set_endpoint_filter_kwargs(endpoint_filter) def get_token(self, auth=None): """Return a token as provided by the auth plugin. :param auth: The auth plugin to use for token. Overrides the plugin on the session. (optional) :type auth: :class:`keystoneclient.auth.base.BaseAuthPlugin` :raises AuthorizationFailure: if a new token fetch fails. :returns string: A valid token. """ return self.session.get_token(auth or self.auth) def get_endpoint(self, auth=None, **kwargs): """Get an endpoint as provided by the auth plugin. :param auth: The auth plugin to use for token. Overrides the plugin on the session. (optional) :type auth: :class:`keystoneclient.auth.base.BaseAuthPlugin` :raises MissingAuthPlugin: if a plugin is not available. :returns string: An endpoint if available or None. """ self._set_endpoint_filter_kwargs(kwargs) return self.session.get_endpoint(auth or self.auth, **kwargs) def invalidate(self, auth=None): """Invalidate an authentication plugin.""" return self.session.invalidate(auth or self.auth)
deleted_lines: if self.service_type: endpoint_filter.setdefault('service_type', self.service_type) if self.service_name: endpoint_filter.setdefault('service_name', self.service_name) if self.interface: endpoint_filter.setdefault('interface', self.interface) if self.region_name: endpoint_filter.setdefault('region_name', self.region_name) if self.version: endpoint_filter.setdefault('version', self.version)

commit_message:
Additional testing of reverse workflow

* Added engine based tests for reverse workflow
* Fixed workflow handler tests
* Fixed the algorithm of searching next workflow tasks

Change-Id: I0ae430e9f4238a366b0c20abbf3e05753826e363
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/87/120987/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 - Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from mistral.db.v2 import api as db_api from mistral.openstack.common import log as logging from mistral.services import workbooks as wb_service from mistral.tests.unit.engine1 import base from mistral.workflow import states LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) # Use the set_default method to set value otherwise in certain test cases # the change in value is not permanent. cfg.CONF.set_default('auth_enable', False, group='pecan') WORKBOOK = """ --- Version: '2.0' Workflows: wf1: type: reverse parameters: - param1 - param2 tasks: task1: action: std.echo output='{$.param1}' publish: result1: $ task2: action: std.echo output="{$.result1} & {$.param2}" publish: result2: $ requires: [task1] """ class SubworkflowsTest(base.EngineTestCase): def setUp(self): super(SubworkflowsTest, self).setUp() wb_service.create_workbook_v2({ 'name': 'my_wb', 'definition': WORKBOOK, 'tags': ['test'] }) def test_start_task1(self): wf_input = {'param1': 'a', 'param2': 'b'} exec_db = self.engine.start_workflow( 'my_wb.wf1', wf_input, task_name='task1' ) # Execution 1. self.assertIsNotNone(exec_db) self.assertDictEqual(wf_input, exec_db.input) self.assertDictEqual({'task_name': 'task1'}, exec_db.start_params) # Wait till workflow 'wf1' is completed. self._await(lambda: self.is_execution_success(exec_db.id)) exec_db = db_api.get_execution(exec_db.id) self.assertEqual(1, len(exec_db.tasks)) self.assertEqual(1, len(db_api.get_tasks())) self._assert_single_item( exec_db.tasks, name='task1', state=states.SUCCESS ) self.assertEqual('a', exec_db.output['task']['task1']) self._assert_dict_contains_subset({'result1': 'a'}, exec_db.output) def test_start_task2(self): wf_input = {'param1': 'a', 'param2': 'b'} exec_db = self.engine.start_workflow( 'my_wb.wf1', wf_input, task_name='task2' ) # Execution 1. self.assertIsNotNone(exec_db) self.assertDictEqual(wf_input, exec_db.input) self.assertDictEqual({'task_name': 'task2'}, exec_db.start_params) # Wait till workflow 'wf1' is completed. self._await(lambda: self.is_execution_success(exec_db.id)) exec_db = db_api.get_execution(exec_db.id) self.assertEqual(2, len(exec_db.tasks)) self.assertEqual(2, len(db_api.get_tasks())) self._assert_single_item( exec_db.tasks, name='task1', state=states.SUCCESS ) self._assert_single_item( exec_db.tasks, name='task2', state=states.SUCCESS ) self.assertEqual('a', exec_db.output['task']['task1']) self.assertEqual('a & b', exec_db.output['task']['task2']) self._assert_dict_contains_subset({'result1': 'a'}, exec_db.output) self._assert_dict_contains_subset({'result2': 'a & b'}, exec_db.output)

commit_message:
opensuse: Support pkg removal in install-packages

Add "-e" option to remove packages. This is needed for
elements/package-installs/bin/package-uninstalls which calls
"install-packages -e".

Change-Id: I673942f505d5278e6015324950f6e1455ba50805

Fix spelling of controller0_VLANPort

Prior to this change, using these templates fails as
controller0_VLANPort is defined, but we attempt to use
controller0VLANPort instead.

commit_message:
Update virsh dumpxml ssh command

This patch adds a new regex for an updated virsh dumpxml ssh command.
Once Nova BM is removed we will put up patch that removes the current
dumpxml regex, but until then we will need both.

Change-Id: I10b49751d55946b8977eed3998612362c740b104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/99/120799/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: r"""^/usr/bin/virsh( --connect qemu:///system)? dumpxml [a-z0-9_]+ \| awk -F "'" '/mac address/{print \$2}'\| tr -d ':'$""": run_command,

commit_message:
NSX: Correct allowed_address_pair return value on create_port

This patch fixes the NSX plugin to return [] rather than None for a
port does not have any allowed_address_pairs when a create_port api
call is made. Currently the NSX plugin is failing every patch because
now tempest is checking for this value to be [].

Change-Id: Ic82c564ff62000c367c544f44a76694be9375790
Closes-bug: 1366921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/64/119864/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_create_port_no_allowed_address_pairs(self): with self.network() as net: res = self._create_port(self.fmt, net['network']['id']) port = self.deserialize(self.fmt, res) self.assertEqual(port['port'][addr_pair.ADDRESS_PAIRS], []) self._delete('ports', port['port']['id'])

commit_message:
Add V3 JSON Home support to GET /

The server wasn't returning a JSON Home response for GET / when the
Accept header is `application/json-home`. By returning the V3 JSON
Home response for GET / a V3 client that supports JSON Home can
GET either /v3 or / and use the response. The identity API should
be able to be set to /.

Closes-Bug: #1366589
Change-Id: I3191a85acf9d2f582f6b48a164cf5ac2bf84a8cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/40/118240/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import webob from keystone.common import json_homefrom keystone.openstack.common import jsonutilsdef request_v3_json_home(new_prefix): # FIXME(blk-u): the v3_router needs to be injected into the version # controller somehow. from keystone import service if not service.v3_router: # No V3 router, so just return an empty JSON Home doc. return {'resources': {}} req = webob.Request.blank( '/', headers={'Accept': 'application/json-home'}) v3_json_home_str = req.get_response(service.v3_router).body v3_json_home = jsonutils.loads(v3_json_home_str) json_home.translate_urls(v3_json_home, new_prefix) return v3_json_home def version_accept_best_match(context): req_mime_type = version_accept_best_match(context) if req_mime_type == MimeTypes.JSON_HOME: v3_json_home = request_v3_json_home('/v3') return wsgi.render_response( body=v3_json_home, headers=(('Content-Type', MimeTypes.JSON_HOME),)) req_mime_type = version_accept_best_match(context) if req_mime_type == MimeTypes.JSON_HOME: v3_json_home = request_v3_json_home('/../v3') return wsgi.render_response( body=v3_json_home, headers=(('Content-Type', MimeTypes.JSON_HOME),)) req_mime_type = version_accept_best_match(context)

subject: Add quotas for Server Groups (V2 API compatibility & V2.1 support)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-04 21:14:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4484457f01ee9b0010ad269cc17f475b99bf6d99', 'message': 'Add quotas for Server Groups

Server groups can be used to control the affinity and anti-affinity
scheduling policy for a group of servers (instances).  Whilst this is
a useful mechanism for users such scheduling decisions need to be
balanced by a deployers requirements to make effective use of the
available capacity.

This change adds quota values to constrain the number and size of
server groups a user can create.

Two new quota values are be introduced to limit the number of server
groups and the number of servers in a server group. These will follow
the existing pattern for quotas in that:

* They are defined by config values, which also include the default
  value

* They can be defined per project or per user within a project

* A value of -1 for either quota will be treated as unlimited

* Defaults can be set via the quota groups API

* Values may be changed at any time but will only take effect at the next
  server group or server create.   Reducing the quota will not affect any
  existing groups, but new servers will not be allowed into group
  that have become over quota.

Implements: blueprint server-group-quotas
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib281e43eabfbd176454bde7f0622d46fb04fcb79

'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2014-08-21 16:04:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/642282a4ae02c61cd2827b15699403fc4f8364b7', 'message': 'Add quotas for Server Groups

Server groups can be used to control the affinity and anti-affinity
scheduling policy for a group of servers (instances).  Whilst this is
a useful mechanism for users such scheduling decisions need to be
balanced by a deployers requirements to make effective use of the
available capacity.

This change adds quota values to constrain the number and size of
server groups a user can create.

Two new quota values are be introduced to limit the number of server
groups and the number of servers in a server group. These will follow
the existing pattern for quotas in that:

* They are defined by config values, which also include the default
  value

* They can be defined per project or per user within a project

* A value of -1 for either quota will be treated as unlimited

* Defaults can be set via the quota groups API

* Values may be changed at any time but will only take effect at the next
  server group or server create.   Reducing the quota will not affect any
  existing groups, but new servers will not be allowed into group
  that have become over quota.

This is part one of a linked sequences of changes that implement the
new quotas - split to keep make the reviews easier.

This part adds the definition of the new quota values, but leaves the
V2 API unchanged.  The V3 API is updated as it shows all quota values.

The second part adds the new V2 API extension to make the new quota
values visible and changeable.  At this point a Tempest change is
required to get a clean run as it checks for a specific set of
values.

The third part implements the quota checks themselves.

Co-Author: Cyril Roelandt (Server Group Quota Unit tests)

Implements: blueprint server-group-quotas
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib281e43eabfbd176454bde7f0622d46fb04fcb79

groups and the number of servers in a server group. These will follow
the existing pattern for quotas in that:

* They are defined by config values, which also include the default
  value

* They can be defined per project or per user within a project

* A value of -1 for either quota will be treated as unlimited

* Defaults can be set via the quota groups API

* Values may be changed at any time but will only take effect at the next
  server group or server create.   Reducing the quota will not affect any
  existing groups, but new servers will not be allowed into group
  that have become over quota.

This is part one of a linked sequences of changes that implement the
new quotas - split to make the reviews easier.

This part adds the definition of the new quota values, but leaves the
V2 API unchanged.  The V2.1 API is updated as it shows all quota values.

The second part adds the new V2 API extension to make the new quota
values visible and changeable.  At this point a Tempest change is
required to get a clean run as it checks for a specific set of
values.

The third part implements the quota checks themselves.

Thanks to Cyril Roelandt for supplying some of the unit tests.

Co-authored-by: Cyril Roelandt <cyril.roelandt@enovance.com>

Implements: blueprint server-group-quotas
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib281e43eabfbd176454bde7f0622d46fb04fcb79

commit_message:
Add quotas for Server Groups (V2 API compatibility & V2.1 support)

Server groups can be used to control the affinity and anti-affinity
scheduling policy for a group of servers (instances).  Whilst this is
a useful mechanism for users such scheduling decisions need to be
balanced by a deployers requirements to make effective use of the
available capacity.

This change adds quota values to constrain the number and size of
server groups a user can create.

Two new quota values are be introduced to limit the number of server
groups and the number of servers in a server group. These will follow
the existing pattern for quotas in that:

* They are defined by config values, which also include the default
  value

* They can be defined per project or per user within a project

* A value of -1 for either quota will be treated as unlimited

* Defaults can be set via the quota groups API

* Values may be changed at any time but will only take effect at the next
  server group or server create.   Reducing the quota will not affect any
  existing groups, but new servers will not be allowed into group
  that have become over quota.

This is part one of a linked sequences of changes that implement the
new quotas - split to make the reviews easier.

This part adds the definition of the new quota values, but leaves the
V2 API unchanged.  The V2.1 API is updated as it shows all quota values.

The second part adds the new V2 API extension to make the new quota
values visible and changeable.  At this point a Tempest change is
required to get a clean run as it checks for a specific set of
values.

The third part implements the quota checks themselves.

Thanks to Cyril Roelandt for supplying some of the unit tests.

Co-authored-by: Cyril Roelandt <cyril.roelandt@enovance.com>

Implements: blueprint server-group-quotas
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib281e43eabfbd176454bde7f0622d46fb04fcb79

commit_message:
Improve the selectability of Swift tests

Before this commit, Tempest tests of Swift were selectable only for WSGI
middleware on proxy servers. With this commit, other following Swift
functions are also selectable with Tempest's config file.

Following Swift functions are selectable now:
 - Old-style Container Sync: mirroring objects in the container to another
   container
 - Object Versioning: versioning all objects in the container
 - Discoverability: providing details about the Swift installation

Implements blueprint more-selectable-swift-tests

Change-Id: Idd4afb675c70eea6ba4f8ce59c635f32f040c61e

commit_message:
Added new filter class for sub-service tables

The same filter class was being run on almost every system info table
despite them having different attributes which was causing horizon to
break. New filter class filters on the 'binary' attribute of the
cinder and nova sub-services.

Change-Id: Idc69a58ee4705280e44bc81bcd429c58da00e6f1
Closes-Bug: 1363250

added_lines: class SubServiceFilterAction(tables.FilterAction): def filter(self, table, services, filter_string): q = filter_string.lower() def comp(service): if q in service.binary.lower(): return True return False return filter(comp, services) table_actions = (SubServiceFilterAction,) table_actions = (SubServiceFilterAction,)

commit_message:
Sync jsonutils from oslo-incubator 32e7f0b5

Syncs the jsonutils module from oslo-incubator using commit
32e7f0b56f527427544050f251999f3de588ac93 .

Note that since there's a feature change in oslo-incubator I'm
switching to module syncs.

 $ ./update.sh --nodeps --base keystone --dest-dir ../keystone \
     --modules jsonutils

This change includes the following commit
-----------------------------------------
d9060f6 Check for namedtuple_as_object support before using it

Change-Id: I152faacdbb394209f87b91a699bb4ca185c2125e
Closes-Bug: #1361230

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-04 10:19:52.000000000', 'files': ['elements/swift/os-refresh-config/configure.d/73-swift'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/c6f8b5d301147db9d9e4870e9c08372306b21b1e', 'message': 'Allow swift "min_part_hours" to be configurable

commit_message:
Allow swift "min_part_hours" to be configurable

With swift rings, a "min_part_hours" value is required. This is the
time (in hours) before a specific partition can be moved in succession
(following a rebalance). Currently this value is hard-coded to 1 but
this value is not feasible for a large system and it can often take
several hours for partitions to re-align following a rebalance.

Therefore, this change allows this value to be configurable by adding
the "MIN_PART_HOURS" variable. If this change is accepted, I will add
the relevant parameter in tripleo-heat-templates.

Change-Id: Ie6438386a54794e1ae2f31ad925db01c2c10ed6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/24/119024/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MIN_PART_HOURS=$(os-apply-config --key swift.min-part-hours --key-default 1)swift-ring-builder /etc/swift/object.builder create $PARTPOWER $REPLICAS $MIN_PART_HOURS swift-ring-builder /etc/swift/container.builder create $PARTPOWER $REPLICAS $MIN_PART_HOURS swift-ring-builder /etc/swift/account.builder create $PARTPOWER $REPLICAS $MIN_PART_HOURS

commit_message:
Retype the volume with correct empty QoS

Currently for storwzie driver, if the new type does not have QoS
configurations, the old QoS configurations remain in the volume after retyping
it. It should be retyped into a volume with empty QoS.

Change-Id: I417ca06a74c9c8c6dc840f2fd348292073bd5ddf
Closes-Bug: #1368595

commit_message:
javelin: fix object destruction

When adding "destroy" support in javelin, a wrong condition has been
introduced to validate if an object has been destroyed or not by its
HTTP return code.

204 is returned and was considered as an error, which is wrong.
Also, delete a resource cleanup dupplication (servers).

Change-Id: I1adaf143ebf2de90d1b2cafc91dcd3a521b96fec
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

commit_message:
Remove bypassing of H302 for gettextutils markers

When we used the i18n markers (_, _LE, _LW, etc) from
ironic.openstack.common.gettextutils, we bypassed H302
hacking rule for them (via tox.ini file). Now that we've
converted to using the markers from oslo.i18n and are no
longer using the markers from gettextutils, we can remove
the bypass stuff.

Change-Id: I26147b69884cd9c075e1cfe38a92e38e861083e7
Closes-Bug: #1368425

commit_message:
Add openvswitch-datapath mapping for SUSE

On SUSE family distros, there is no openvswitch-datapath
packaged. Map to the correct package name.

Change-Id: I1c174fe5986ec9ac5e88642b75c1e27294e1fade

commit_message:
Add sort_key and sort_dir parameters to *-list

These arguments are using for sorting the result on the server.
Small refactoring was conducted to seperate processing of
common arguments for all lists into the utility function.

Change-Id: I33be1fcecc665c8f2207e53b24ff47954d80dc60
Closes-Bug: #1339731
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/55/114555/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def common_params_for_list(args, fields, field_labels): params = {} if args.marker is not None: params['marker'] = args.marker if args.limit is not None: params['limit'] = args.limit if args.sort_key is not None: # Support using both heading and field name for sort_key fields_map = dict(zip(field_labels, fields)) try: sort_key = fields_map[args.sort_key] except KeyError: if args.sort_key in fields: sort_key = args.sort_key else: raise exc.CommandError( _("%s is not a valid field for sorting") % args.sort_key) params['sort_key'] = sort_key if args.sort_dir is not None: if args.sort_dir not in ('asc', 'desc'): raise exc.CommandError( _("%s is not valid value for sort direction, " "valid are 'asc' and 'desc'") % args.sort_dir) params['sort_dir'] = args.sort_dir return params

commit_message:
Remove workaround for Ubuntu kernel permissions

Without the dependency on python-guestfs in Icehouse, we no
longer need to provide a workaround for Ubuntu kernel
permission issues on compute nodes.

Change-Id: Ib1d5225c138b1d9d63948b587ff53daded010100
Closes-Bug: #1343738
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/59/120559/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: <step os="ubuntu"> <para>For security reasons, the Linux kernel is not readable by normal users which restricts hypervisor services such as qemu and libguestfs. For details, see <link xlink:href="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/759725" >this bug</link>. To make the current kernel readable, run: <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>dpkg-statoverride --update --add root root 0644 /boot/vmlinuz-$(uname -r)</userinput></screen> To also enable this override for all future kernel updates, create the file <filename>/etc/kernel/postinst.d/statoverride</filename> containing:<programlisting language="bash">#!/bin/sh version="$1" # passing the kernel version is required [ -z "${version}" ] && exit 0 dpkg-statoverride --update --add root root 0644 /boot/vmlinuz-${version}</programlisting> Remember to make the file executable: <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chmod +x /etc/kernel/postinst.d/statoverride</userinput></screen> </para> </step>

commit_message:
Fix host listing in live migration

The live migration selector needs to offer a list
of hosts, not a list of hypervisors.

Change-Id: I73c1175a5f87b0f91e36083f05467c26feca5d51
Closes-Bug: #1335999

commit_message:
Extra unit tests for check_delete_headers

A few extra tests to verify check_delete_headers in
constraints.py. A little duplication of coverage of existing
proxy/controllers/test_obj.py:TestObjController.test_POST_delete_at
but these tests call the recently refactored function directly,
and also add tests for X-Delete-After taking precedence over
X-Delete-At.

Change-Id: I129cef15a6feac8a60fd4efbb3535d93f0eaab36
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/56/119756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_check_delete_headers_sets_delete_at(self): t = time.time() + 1000 # check delete-at is passed through headers = {'Content-Length': '0', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain', 'X-Delete-At': str(int(t))} req = Request.blank('/', headers=headers) constraints.check_delete_headers(req) self.assertTrue('X-Delete-At' in req.headers) self.assertEqual(req.headers['X-Delete-At'], str(int(t))) # check delete-after is converted to delete-at headers = {'Content-Length': '0', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain', 'X-Delete-After': '42'} req = Request.blank('/', headers=headers) with mock.patch('time.time', lambda: t): constraints.check_delete_headers(req) self.assertTrue('X-Delete-At' in req.headers) expected = str(int(t) + 42) self.assertEqual(req.headers['X-Delete-At'], expected) # check delete-after takes precedence over delete-at headers = {'Content-Length': '0', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain', 'X-Delete-After': '42', 'X-Delete-At': str(int(t) + 40)} req = Request.blank('/', headers=headers) with mock.patch('time.time', lambda: t): constraints.check_delete_headers(req) self.assertTrue('X-Delete-At' in req.headers) self.assertEqual(req.headers['X-Delete-At'], expected) headers = {'Content-Length': '0', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain', 'X-Delete-After': '42', 'X-Delete-At': str(int(t) + 44)} req = Request.blank('/', headers=headers) with mock.patch('time.time', lambda: t): constraints.check_delete_headers(req) self.assertTrue('X-Delete-At' in req.headers) self.assertEqual(req.headers['X-Delete-At'], expected)

commit_message:
moving object validation checks to top of PUT method

This adds a sanity check on x-delete headers as
part of check_object_creation method

Change-Id: If5069469e433189235b1178ea203b5c8a926f553
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

added_lines: from neutron.common import constants def test_get_device_details_without_port_context(self): self.manager.get_plugin().get_bound_port_context.return_value = None res = self.callbacks.get_device_details(rpc_context='fake_context', device='fake_device') self.assertEqual(res, {'device': 'fake_device'}) def _test_get_device_details_port_status_equal_new_status(self, admin_state_up): port = {'status': constants.PORT_STATUS_BUILD, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up, 'network_id': 'fake', 'mac_address': 'fake', 'fixed_ips': 'fake', 'device_owner': 'fake', 'binding:profile': 'fake'} self.manager.get_plugin().get_bound_port_context().current = port self.callbacks.get_device_details(rpc_context='fake_context', host='fake_host') self.manager.get_plugin().update_port_status.assert_call_count( 0 if admin_state_up else 1) def test_get_device_details_port_status_equal_new_status(self): self._test_get_device_details_port_status_equal_new_status(True) def test_get_device_details_port_status_not_equal_new_status(self): self._test_get_device_details_port_status_equal_new_status(False) def test_get_devices_details_list(self): devices = list(range(5)) with mock.patch.object(self.callbacks, 'get_device_details', side_effect=devices) as f: res = self.callbacks.get_devices_details_list('fake_context', fake='fake', devices=devices) self.assertEqual(res, devices) calls = [mock.call('fake_context', device=i, fake='fake') for i in devices] f.assert_has_calls(calls) f.assert_call_count = 5 res = self.callbacks.get_devices_details_list('fake_context') self.assertEqual(res, []) def test_get_devices_details_list_with_empty_devices(self): with mock.patch.object(self.callbacks, 'get_device_details') as f: res = self.callbacks.get_devices_details_list('fake_context') f.assert_call_count = 0 self.assertEqual(res, []) def test_update_device_up_with_device_not_bound_to_host(self): self.manager.get_plugin().port_bound_to_host.return_value = False self.assertIsNone(self.callbacks.update_device_up('fake_context', host=True)) def test_update_device_down_with_device_not_bound_to_host(self): self.manager.get_plugin().port_bound_to_host.return_value = False self.assertEqual( self.callbacks.update_device_down('fake_context', device='fake_device', host=True), {'device': 'fake_device', 'exists': True})

commit_message:
Fix rootwrap for non openstack.org iqn's

The encryption methods implemented for attached volumes
require a symbolic link created to the /dev/disk-by* iqn.

The current implementation works fine for LVM, however the rootwrap
is restricted to only allow iqns of the form openstack.org, for
vendors that use their own target and iqn this won't work and will
result in the attach failing for unauthorized command.

This just makes the regex for the rootwrap filter a bit more
permissive, only looking for iscsi-iqn.*

Change-Id: I023ad24867c045a88f72c5ac7ac4e4da097a3643
Closes-Bug: 1362854
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/52/117652/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ln: RegExpFilter, ln, root, ln, --symbolic, --force, /dev/mapper/ip-.*-iscsi-iqn.*, /dev/disk/by-path/ip-.*-iscsi-iqn.*

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-10 16:40:16.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/common/ldap/core.py', 'keystone/assignment/backends/ldap.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/17e8b7a6333ee92a87bf0a7f3672e6426e6987b2', 'message': 'LDAP: refactor use of "1.1" OID

I've noticed several people asking questions about the arbitrary usage
of ['1.1'] in code review, so I figured I'd refactor them into a
constant so it's a bit more self-documenting, since it's definition is,
in fact, completely arbitrary:

    If the client does not want any attributes returned, it can specify
    a list containing only the attribute with OID "1.1". This OID was
    chosen arbitrarily and does not correspond to any attribute in use.

Source: http://www.alvestrand.no/objectid/1.1.html

Change-Id: Ib2901bd8593b5a6ea8b6a5488f0d45b51fa8b77c
'}]
commit_message:
LDAP: refactor use of "1.1" OID

I've noticed several people asking questions about the arbitrary usage
of ['1.1'] in code review, so I figured I'd refactor them into a
constant so it's a bit more self-documenting, since it's definition is,
in fact, completely arbitrary:

    If the client does not want any attributes returned, it can specify
    a list containing only the attribute with OID "1.1". This OID was
    chosen arbitrarily and does not correspond to any attribute in use.

Source: http://www.alvestrand.no/objectid/1.1.html

Change-Id: Ib2901bd8593b5a6ea8b6a5488f0d45b51fa8b77c

Change-Id: Ie17871f42f75085c2ac6a14fb1526df7bc3a9603

commit_message:
Log translation hint for Heat.api

Currently, Log translation is motivated by oslo's move to prioritized
translation of strings, as documented at
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards#Log_Translation

- add log translation hints for warning, error and info levels
- move from LOG.warning to LOG.warn
- remove use of % as a string formatter, use the log functionality
  instead

Partial implements blueprint log-translation-hints

Change-Id: Ie17871f42f75085c2ac6a14fb1526df7bc3a9603

commit_message:
Reduce unused tox environments

Since the openstack-ci only tests 5 of the many tox enviroments
we had listed and from my knowledge nobody else is testing using
those other non-standard enviroments just reduce the set of applicable
environments to the ones that are being used (which also means we
can remove the usage of toxgen and just stick with a simpler file
that is easier to use, modify and adjust).

Change-Id: I4d2302594b9f9e8741f9693cb358efc1418bd45d

commit_message:
Fix service groups with zookeeper

Service groups using zookeeper don't work due to apparently improper
handling of the zookeeper session creation.

No additional unit tests as the mocking these interfaces probably
doesn't actually provide substantial future guaruntees. The correct
long term fix is to enable zk for unit testing upstream.

Change-Id: I21691843cb4936d10a0b82df41aef3afe5bf2519
Closes-bug: #1239864

commit_message:
Allow adding or changing the CSS classes of a data table

Sometimes a datatable needs to be displayed slightly differently, for
instance with or without the borders, condensed, zebra, etc. This patch
lets us do that in two ways.

It adds a css_class option to table's Meta, so that we can easily add
more classes to a particular table, and modify its looks with CSS.

It also puts the whole table's CSS class list in a block, so that we
can inherit from the table's template to completely replace its classes,
if we need to.

Change-Id: I64a1f3ba8d80643c545de024f52ec3313bbff8e5

subject: Skip boto instance test with neutron
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-05 05:25:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/14755668d0e94d7cf8ee93c811d567c678e88d88', 'message': 'Fix boto tests network tear-down issues

In [1] I have identified that the boto tests aren't actually running
on Ubuntu due to an error creating the boot images which is undetected
as a failure by devstack.  However, I can not get this change in, as
tempest.thirdparty.boto.test_ec2_instance_run.InstanceRunTest keeps
failing in tearDownClass() due to:

    "Unable to complete operation on subnet [...]. One or more ports
    have an IP allocation from this subnet"

Full logs at [2].  What I did notice, however, was that this test
works on Fedora 20 [3].  The difference there is that setUpClass() was
*not* creating the isolated network resources (grep [2] & [3] for
InstanceRunTest:setUpClass)

I can not really explain why on Ubuntu the isolated network gets
created as part of class setup, and on Fedora it doesn't.  However,
the correct thing to do seems to be to explicitly not create it.

Closes-Bug: #1365831

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/113767/
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/67/113767/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full/f7610f8/logs/tempest.txt.gz
[3] http://logs.openstack.org/39/112739/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-f20/6781e53/logs/tempest.txt.gz

Change-Id: I626aa32c49233a1c9b59cd471ce4c2860431bd9e

commit_message:
Skip boto instance test with neutron

In [1] I have identified that the boto tests aren't actually running
on Ubuntu due to an error creating the boot images which is undetected
as a failure by devstack.  However, I can not get this change in, as
tempest.thirdparty.boto.test_ec2_instance_run.InstanceRunTest keeps
failing in tearDownClass() due to:

    "Unable to complete operation on subnet [...]. One or more ports
    have an IP allocation from this subnet"

Full logs at [2].  While we are working on this, skip this test on
neutron so other tests don't futher bit-rot

Partial-Bug: #1365831

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/113767/
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/67/113767/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full/f7610f8/logs/tempest.txt.gz

Change-Id: I626aa32c49233a1c9b59cd471ce4c2860431bd9e

were added.

commit_message:
Enable upload object button without user input.

This fix changes the behaviour of the the "Upload Object" button for Swift to
be enabled by default. There was a check to disable the button if there were
no user changes, but that does not make too much sense since you can only upload
an object if you explicitly change the name of the object.

Change-Id: Ib2d14bec55d858dbc82981336a4373a87bf876e0
Closes-Bug: #1367093

commit_message:
Increase CEPH_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE_DEFAULT to 4GB

CEPH_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE_DEFAULT should be more than 2GB
to make volume snapshot feature works. 2GB is not enough
because min Cinder volume size is 1GB and no snapshot
could be created.

This also fixes related Tempest tests and experimental
check-tempest-dsvm-full-ceph gate job.

Change-Id: Ifa41d0d1764d68ea02dcb32a5fc62f7f6282904d

commit_message:
Test against latest glance_store code

Install glance_store from git so we can test Glance against master. This
is useful for both, glance and glance_store gates, to make sure nothing
is broken there.

Change-Id: I6c01165c4384c41f46f2c32d64475703b3178dab

commit_message:
Remove binding:profile update from Mellanox ML2 MD

Remove temporary work-around that populates physical_network in
binding:profile. Now when both neutron and nova use binding:vif_details
to pass attributes to plug neutron port, this work-around is not nequired.
Remove related temporary code from ML2 plugin.

Change-Id: Ib37203af396f31080b1b27b500a571c20917f5a4
Closes-Bug: 1360762

  resources to reflect current code behaviour

commit_message:
add instruction how to cleanup NSX cluster

- provide user with instruction notes how to cleanup NSX cluster, when
  deployment failed or was stopped

Change-Id: Ib06962774a440c067f5bdbf1032dbf85e6ec98a8
Closes-bug: #1367085
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/94/120494/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Eventually, the cluster may run out of resources; it is up to the cloud operator to remove needless entities from the VMware NSX cluster. You have to clean NSX cluster when deployment failed or was interrupted and after solving problem, you want to start deployment process again. To cleanup NSX cluster, log into NSX Manager, open dashboard and click on number link in "Hypervisor Software Version Summary": .. image:: /_images/nsx-cleanup-1.png Tick all registered nodes and press "Delete Checked" button: .. image:: /_images/nsx-cleanup-2.png :width: 60% Then click on "Logical Layer" in "Category" column, tick all remaining logical entities and remove them by pressing corresponding "Delete Checked" button: .. image:: /_images/nsx-cleanup-3.png :width: 60%
deleted_lines: Eventually, the cluster may run out of resources; it is up to the cloud operator to remove needless entities from the VMware NSX cluster.

commit_message:
Use action_handler_task for delete_snapshot

Change-Id: Ic63d466ab325c801f43b5bdcb130870845dd1c34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/72/117472/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @scheduler.wrappertask def delete_snapshot(self, data): yield self.action_handler_task('delete_snapshot', args=[data])
deleted_lines: def delete_snapshot(self, data): handle_delete_snapshot = getattr( self, 'handle_delete_snapshot', None) if callable(handle_delete_snapshot): handle_data = handle_delete_snapshot(data) check = getattr(self, 'check_delete_snapshot_complete', None) if callable(check): while not check(handle_data): yield

commit_message:
Fix DBReferenceError on MySQL and SQLite

It turns out the test was wrong as the error message used was not a good
one. Real world tests showed that, so I've updated the test and the code
to work.

Refactored tests to use real backends, fix error message for SQLite.

Co-Authored-By: Victor Sergeyev <vsergeyev@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ifa64478a9ac9ed0a3c317a8974615b770c85f313

commit_message:
Configure the stores explicitly

The store configure() method is being called two times: on one hand
in the store constructor and also explicitly in the create_stores()
method.

Since the configure() method can contain remote calls, it is better
to avoid calling it more than once, especially, when it doesn't add
any value.

Change-Id: I6f39dfa7fd3d0ef7ff4fc2a9ebbebdfb0cf114a1

subject: Clarify logging in lockutils
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-11 20:08:14.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/lockutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/bbb266c59ea3f03c83a6df67cde47f75ecd7e2db', 'message': 'Clarify logging in lockutils

The old logging statements in lockutils made for some confusing log
entries where it would appear a given lock was acquired multiple
times by different threads at the same time.  See referenced bug
for details.

In order to alleviate that confusion, this change does a few things:
1) Adds an explicit "acquired" message inside the lock so it is
   clear when the lock was actually acquired.
2) Moves the release message inside the semaphore so there's no
   chance of it being logged out of order.
3) Removes the "Got semaphore" message and splits it into two
   separate messages depending on whether the semaphore was found
   in the weakref dictionary.  Making it clear which code path
   was followed should help with future debugging.

This is the incubator port of olso.concurrency change
I0fbb473c60d48c9704597d9e3634402857861a66

Change-Id: If863c9d3896bc786f3c9c46196ebb0766e57d863
Closes-Bug: 1367941
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify logging in lockutils

The old logging statements in lockutils made for some confusing log
entries where it would appear a given lock was acquired multiple
times by different threads at the same time.  See referenced bug
for details.

In order to alleviate that confusion, this change does a few things:
1) Adds an explicit "acquired" message inside the lock so it is
   clear when the lock was actually acquired.
2) Moves the release message inside the semaphore so there's no
   chance of it being logged out of order.
3) Removes the "Got semaphore" message and splits it into two
   separate messages depending on whether the semaphore was found
   in the weakref dictionary.  Making it clear which code path
   was followed should help with future debugging.

This is the incubator port of olso.concurrency change
I0fbb473c60d48c9704597d9e3634402857861a66

Change-Id: If863c9d3896bc786f3c9c46196ebb0766e57d863
Closes-Bug: 1367941

added_lines: class DictSemaphoreContainer(object): def __init__(self): self._semaphores_lock = threading.Lock() self._semaphores = {} def _fetch_internal_lock(self, name): match = self._semaphores.get(name) if match is not None: return match else: sem = threading.Semaphore() self._on_creation(sem, name) self._semaphores[name] = (sem, [0]) return self._semaphores[name] def _on_creation(self, sem, name): LOG.debug('Created semaphore "%(sem)s" with name "%(lock)s"' % {'sem': sem, 'lock': name}) def _on_destroy(self, sem, name): LOG.debug('Destroying semaphore "%(sem)s" with name "%(lock)s"' % {'sem': sem, 'lock': name}) @contextlib.contextmanager def internal_lock(self, name): with self._semaphores_lock: sem, refs = self._fetch_internal_lock(name) refs[0] += 1 try: yield sem finally: with self._semaphores_lock: refs[0] -= 1 if refs[0] <= 0: self._on_destroy(sem, name) self._semaphores.pop(name) _container = DictSemaphoreContainer() internal_lock = _container.internal_lock with internal_lock(name):

commit_message:
Use a new style of semaphore container to see if this fixes

Instead of using a weakref dictionary use a customized container
that we clean up as we consume new semaphores that also has attached
methods to determine when a weak reference is destroyed.

Change-Id: I7e9696fe041fbc6c0be0bd0b72ebf1dcb32488de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/120865/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six class DictSemaphoreContainer(object): def __init__(self): self._semaphores_lock = threading.Lock() self._semaphores = {} def _fetch_internal_lock(self, name): dead = set() match = None # Lazily remove old non-referenced semaphores, we aren't using a # weakref.WeakValueDictionary here to see if it is causing issues, # this should be fine anyways since we don't create millions of these # and scanning for entries should be an amortized operation and with # a custom container we get to see when things die... for (sem_name, sem_ref) in six.iteritems(self._semaphores): sem = sem_ref() if sem is None: dead.add(sem_name) else: if name == sem_name: match = sem if dead: for sem_name in dead: self._semaphores.pop(sem_name) if match is not None: return match else: sem = threading.Semaphore() death_cb = functools.partial(self._on_reference_death, name) ref = weakref.ref(sem, death_cb) self._on_reference_creation(sem, ref, name) self._semaphores[name] = ref return sem def _on_reference_creation(self, sem, ref, name): LOG.debug('Created reference to semaphore "%(sem)s" via reference' ' "%(ref)s" with name "%(lock)s"' % {'sem': sem, 'ref': ref, 'lock': name}) def _on_reference_death(self, name, ref): LOG.debug('Destroying reference "%(ref)s" to semaphore with' ' name "%(lock)s"' % {'ref': ref, 'lock': name}) def internal_lock(self, name): with self._semaphores_lock: return self._fetch_internal_lock(name) _container = DictSemaphoreContainer() internal_lock = _container.internal_lock
deleted_lines: _semaphores = weakref.WeakValueDictionary() _semaphores_lock = threading.Lock()def internal_lock(name): with _semaphores_lock: try: sem = _semaphores[name] except KeyError: sem = threading.Semaphore() _semaphores[name] = sem LOG.debug('Got semaphore "%(lock)s"', {'lock': name}) return sem

subject: Set revoke_api attribute to None on provider object
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-22 20:24:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/b309915afb6aa6b276d1e5ba17d1872433abb577', 'message': "Set revoke_api attribute to None on provider object

When an optional extension such as revoke_api is not
included in the pipeline.  Keystone was not setting the attribute to None.

commit_message:
Set revoke_api attribute to None on provider object

When an optional extension such as revoke_api is not
included in the pipeline.  Keystone was not setting the attribute to None.
This resulted in validate call raising the following error:

    AttributeError: 'Provider' object has no attribute 'revoke_api'

Change-Id: I15fe304f759cafb6cc5637ede0529571274b4fe0
Closes-bug: #1315049
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/74/116374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: setattr(obj, dependency, None)

revisions:

Adds a bunch of INFO logging in the multiprocess API test so that we can

Renames the _terminate_workers() method to _wait_for_workers_to_end(),
as that accurately describes what that method was really doing, and adds

commit_message:
Adds log statements in multiprocess API test

Adds a bunch of INFO logging in the multiprocess API test so that we can
perhaps get some better information to debug with when a timeout
actually occurs for bug #1357578.

Renames the _terminate_workers() method to _wait_for_workers_to_end(),
as that accurately describes what that method was really doing, and adds
a new _terminate_workers() method to actually stop the
workers (used in tearDown() when the test_restart_sighup() method does
not actually stop the API worker processes like the other test methods
do).

Change-Id: I83731fcaeb9265fc46472ef3a505d1184d44bfe8
Related-bug: #1357578
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/120901/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: workers = [p for p, pp in processes if pp == self.pid] LOG.info('in _get_workers(), workers: %r for PPID %d', workers, self.pid) return workers LOG.warning("Got non-ESRCH errno %d when attempting " "status of worker PID %d", err.errno, worker_pid) self._wait_for_all_workers_to_end() for pid in worker_pids: LOG.info("killing worker process %d in parent %d " "in _terminate_workers()", self.pid, pid) os.kill(pid, signal.SIGTERM) LOG.info("killed worker process %d in parent %d " "in terminate_workers()", pid, self.pid) def _wait_for_all_workers_to_end(self): worker_pids = self._get_workers()
deleted_lines: return [p for p, pp in processes if pp == self.pid] LOG.info('workers: %r' % end_workers) self._terminate_workers()

commit_message:
Load cfg params conditionally

Some datastores don't support config groups so this should be
conditional.

Also, tightened search by version name.

Change-Id: I2b37ce2e30c2e23b8291cd65c883fd2caadabdad
Closes-Bug: #1366939

Friendly error message while creating security group

creating security group. Before that, there was an
error about no such parameter.

commit_message:
Adding a periodic task to remove zombie proxy users

Changes
* adding periodic task for user removal
* adding a wrapper function for the periodic tasks class to improve
  configuration
* refactoring proxy user delete function to allow a user id

Change-Id: I641e1650e7a5fcd96246e13b7e1d548c4a0dda25
Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication

added_lines: def proxy_domain_users_list(): '''Return a list of all users in the proxy domain.''' admin = k.client_for_admin() domain = domain_for_proxy() if domain: return admin.users.list(domain=domain.id) return [] def proxy_user_delete(username=None, user_id=None): :param user_id: The id of the user to delete, if provided this overrides the username. if not user_id: domain = domain_for_proxy() user_list = admin.users.list(domain=domain.id, name=username) if len(user_list) == 0: raise ex.NotFoundException(value=username, message=_('Failed to find user %s')) if len(user_list) > 1: raise ex.NotFoundException(value=username, message=_('Unexpected results found ' 'when searching for user %s')) user_id = user_list[0].id admin.users.delete(user_id) LOG.debug(_('deleted proxy user id {0}').format(user_id))
deleted_lines: def proxy_user_delete(username): domain = domain_for_proxy() user_list = admin.users.list(domain=domain.id, name=username) if len(user_list) == 0: raise ex.NotFoundException(value=username, message=_('Failed to find user %s')) if len(user_list) > 1: raise ex.NotFoundException(value=username, message=_('Unexpected results found when ' 'searching for user %s')) admin.users.delete(user_list[0].id) LOG.debug(_('deleted proxy user {0}').format(username))

commit_message:
Refactoring DataSources to use proxy user

Changes
* adding constants for trust id and domain name to swift_helper
* refactoring oozie edp workflows to use proxy configs when necessary
* adding tests to exercise proxy domain usage in workflows
* removing credentials requirement for DataSource models when using
  proxy domain
* pruning duplicate MapReduce test
* adding tests for DataSource creation without credentials
* adding Keystone v3 token endpoint to Hadoop core-site.xml when domain
  requested

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication
Change-Id: I38fd1c470d608c3de9d8c140228d7c9666523b23

added_lines: def create_job_exec(type, configs=None, proxy=False): _cje_func = _create_job_exec_with_proxy if proxy else _create_job_exec e = _cje_func(j.id, type, configs) def _create_job_exec_with_proxy(job_id, type, configs=None): j_exec = _create_job_exec(job_id, type, configs) j_exec.id = '00000000-1111-2222-3333-4444444444444444' if not j_exec.job_configs: j_exec.job_configs = {} j_exec.job_configs['proxy_configs'] = { 'proxy_username': 'job_' + j_exec.id, 'proxy_password': '55555555-6666-7777-8888-999999999999', 'proxy_trust_id': '0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef' } return j_exec
deleted_lines: def create_job_exec(type, configs=None): e = _create_job_exec(j.id, type, configs)

commit_message:
Adding trust delegation and removal for proxy users

Changes
* adding a generic keystone client creation function
* adding a function to create proxy user clients
* renaming admin client functions for clarity
* adding token delegation/removal during proxy user creation/deletion
* adding a configuration option for proxy user trust roles

Change-Id: I362a27c1b1d0c5b81d6fbbb91fc0689e339f0076
Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication

'''Return the current context client.'''def _client(username, password, project_name=None, trust_id=None, domain_name=None): user_domain_name=domain_name,def _admin_client(project_name=None, trust_id=None): username = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_user password = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_password keystone = _client(username=username, password=password, project_name=project_name, trust_id=trust_id) return keystone def client_for_admin(): '''Return the Sahara admin user client.''' return _admin_client( project_name=CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_tenant_name) def client_for_admin_from_trust(trust_id): '''Return the Sahara admin user client scoped to a trust.''' def client_for_proxy_user(username, password, trust_id=None): '''Return a client for the proxy user specified.''' return _client(username=username, password=password, domain_name=CONF.proxy_user_domain_name, trust_id=trust_id)

commit_message:
Adding proxy user creation per job execution

Changes
* adding sahara.utils.proxy module
* adding functions to create and delete proxy users
* adding proxy user creation during job execution
* adding proxy user deletion during job execution status update
* adding sanitization for proxy configs from job execution
* adding unit test for proxy usage detection function

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication
Change-Id: I551a14a3cb5320a27fc6104b35c3b9a08a03abda

commit_message:
Adding configuration and check for proxy domain

Changes
* adding configuration option for use of proxy domain
* adding configuration option for proxy domain name
* adding method to get the Domain object for the proxy

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-swift-trust-authentication
Change-Id: I369de80c918a52db5200865f754c40bc807289e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/54/115654/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sahara.exceptions as ex from sahara.i18n import _LEimport sahara.utils.openstack.keystone as kdef detect_proxy_domain(): '''Detect the presence of the proxy domain If the proxy domain has been requested but cannot be located, the global configuration option is set to None for the convenience of future attempts to use the proxy domain. ''' try: ctx = context.get_admin_context() context.set_ctx(ctx) domain = k.domain_for_proxy() context.set_ctx(None) except ex.NotFoundException as e: LOG.exception(_LE('Domain requested but not found, (reason: %s)'), e) domain = None CONF.proxy_domain_name = None if domain is not None: LOG.info(_LI('Sahara configured to use proxy domain {0}').format( domain.name)) else: LOG.info(_LI('Sahara configured to not use proxy domain.'))

commit_message:
Keystone local authenticate has an unnecessary pending audit record.

Pending should be used for long running operations but local
authenticate is not such an operation.

Change-Id: If06c826c912a973cf133c6dcc6dabe77a392c64a
Closes-Bug: #1366991

commit_message:
List resources with detail

This commit adds support for getting a list of ports, chassis, ports
associated with a node and nodes associated with a chassis with all
attributes, to both the client and the shell CLI.

Closes-Bug: #1366866
Change-Id: If1941de66d70cdbcc3f31cefdbcd4f634e6ce24e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/25/119825/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list(self, limit=None, marker=None, detail=False): :param detail: Optional, boolean whether to return detailed information about ports. path = '' if detail: path += 'detail' if filters: path += '?' + '&'.join(filters)
deleted_lines: def list(self, limit=None, marker=None): path = None if filters: path = '?' + '&'.join(filters)

added_lines: subnets = self._get_subnets_from_network(context, network, def _get_subnets_from_network(self, context, network, instance_host=None): def get_subnets(): subnet_v4 = { 'network_id': network.uuid, 'cidr': network.cidr, 'gateway': network.gateway, 'broadcast': network.broadcast, 'netmask': network.netmask, 'version': 4, 'dns1': network.dns1, 'dns2': network.dns2} # TODO(tr3buchet): I'm noticing we've assumed here that all dns is # v4. this is probably bad as there is no way to # add v6 dns to nova subnet_v6 = { 'network_id': network.uuid, 'cidr': network.cidr_v6, 'gateway': network.gateway_v6, 'broadcast': None, 'netmask': network.netmask_v6, 'version': 6, 'dns1': None, 'dns2': None} def ips_to_strs(net): for key, value in net.items(): if isinstance(value, netaddr.ip.BaseIP): net[key] = str(value) return net return [ips_to_strs(subnet_v4), ips_to_strs(subnet_v6)] for subnet in get_subnets():
deleted_lines: # NOTE(tr3buchet: unless manager subclassing NetworkManager has # already imported ipam, import nova ipam here if not hasattr(self, 'ipam'): self._import_ipam_lib('nova.network.nova_ipam_lib') def _import_ipam_lib(self, ipam_lib): self.ipam = importutils.import_module(ipam_lib).get_ipam_lib(self) subnets = self._get_subnets_from_network(context, network, vif, def _get_subnets_from_network(self, context, network, vif, instance_host=None): # get subnets ipam_subnets = self.ipam.get_subnets_by_net_id(context, network['project_id'], network['uuid'], vif.uuid) for subnet in ipam_subnets: # get the routes for this subnet # NOTE(tr3buchet): default route comes from subnet gateway if subnet.get('id'): routes = self.ipam.get_routes_by_ip_block(context, subnet['id'], network['project_id']) for route in routes: cidr = netaddr.IPNetwork('%s/%s' % (route['destination'], route['netmask'])).cidr subnet_object.add_route( network_model.Route(cidr=str(cidr), gateway=network_model.IP( address=route['gateway'], type='gateway')))

'net_id', 'vif_id', 'project_id') self.assertEqual(['2001:db8::200:ff:fe00:0'], v6_IPs) def test_get_v6_ips_by_interface_bad_id(self): class FakeContext(context.RequestContext): def elevated(self): commit_message:
Document glance v2 commands

The glance v2 commands need to be called as:
glance -os-image-api-version 2 CMD

Implement logic for this and enhance output.
Closes-Bug: #1367430

Change-Id: Ibc81d49494a203c9c8f469a2a0f93e4c1786af7e

commit_message:
Update fedora-rdo-icehouse element

This patch takes advantage of the refactoring of the rdo-icehouse
and enable-packages-install bits.  The reactoring allows other
redhat family os elements also use rdo-icehouse and
enable-packages-install.

This patch also deprecates the fedora-rdo-icehouse-repository element
and removes the dependency on it from fedora-rdo-icehouse.

Change-Id: I4e2391d987a05163bc7d45ad03f80c9f6d555681

commit_message:
Add hooks to workaround patching bugs

Add several pre and post patching hooks and tests
for them.

* Stop or migrate corosync services from controller node
  and return them after the deployment

* Stop openstack services and kill pids that was
  not stopped together with their children

* Remove openstack packages before deployment
  to prevent conflicts during the update and rollback

Change-Id: Icfc17308d955e55b5e5b31a9c17e0b6d13d8ba10
Closes-bug: #1364081
Closes-bug: #1365635
Closes-bug: #1364068
Co-Authored-By: Vladimir Sharshov <vsharshov@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Vladimir Kuklin <vkuklin@mirantis.com>

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. module Astute class StopOSTServices < PreNodeAction def process(deployment_info, context) old_env = deployment_info.first['openstack_version_prev'] return unless old_env Astute.logger.info "Stop all Openstack services hook start" node_uids = deployment_info.collect { |n| n['uid'] } file_content = File.read File.join(File.dirname(__FILE__), 'stop_services.script') target_file = upload_script(context, node_uids, file_content) Astute.logger.info "Running file: #{target_file} on node uids: #{node_uids.join ', '}" response = run_shell_command(context, node_uids, "/usr/bin/ruby #{target_file} |tee /tmp/stop_services.log") if response[:data][:exit_code] != 0 Astute.logger.warn "#{context.task_id}: Script returned error code #{response[:data][:exit_code]}" end Astute.logger.info "#{context.task_id}: Finished stop services pre-patching hook" end #process private def upload_script(context, node_uids, file_content) target_file = '/tmp/stop_services.rb' Astute.logger.info "Uploading file: #{target_file} to nodes uids: #{node_uids.join ', '}" MClient.new(context, "uploadfile", node_uids).upload( :path => target_file, :content => file_content, :user_owner => 'root', :group_owner => 'root', :permissions => '0700', :overwrite => true, :parents => true ) rescue MClientTimeout, MClientError => e Astute.logger.error("#{context.task_id}: mcollective error: #{e.message}") ensure target_file end end #class end #module

subject: labs: fix race in preseed script
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-11 11:59:15.000000000', 'files': ['labs/lib/osbash/netboot/preseed-vbadd.cfg', 'labs/lib/osbash/netboot/preseed-all.cfg'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/training-guides/commit/6052a0455f928c41e72b3c1a4ff5cc0003af11d6', 'message': 'labs: fix race in preseed script

When using the VirtualBox additions, there is a chance that after the
vboxadd service has started, the shared directory is not yet fully
available. In that case, activate_autostart.sh is never run (although
it may appear in time to be deleted).

This patch makes the script from preseed wait for activate_autostart.sh
to become available before it tries to execute it.

Change-Id: I1c2f3ef2f4301f36efec8a70b811ffe97dbaa779
'}]
commit_message:
labs: fix race in preseed script

When using the VirtualBox additions, there is a chance that after the
vboxadd service has started, the shared directory is not yet fully
available. In that case, activate_autostart.sh is never run (although
it may appear in time to be deleted).

This patch makes the script from preseed wait for activate_autostart.sh
to become available before it tries to execute it.

Change-Id: I1c2f3ef2f4301f36efec8a70b811ffe97dbaa779
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/62/120762/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
d-i preseed/late_command string echo "DIR=/home/osbash/.ssh; mkdir \$DIR; wget -O \$DIR/authorized_keys https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mitchellh/vagrant/master/keys/vagrant.pub ; chmod 700 \$DIR; chmod 400 \$DIR/authorized_keys; chown -R osbash:osbash \$DIR; echo 'osbash ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL' >> /etc/sudoers; echo 'Defaults:osbash !requiretty' >> /etc/sudoers; apt-get -y purge virtualbox-guest-dkms virtualbox-guest-utils; mount /dev/sr1 /mnt; /mnt/VBoxLinuxAdditions.run; umount /mnt; echo -e '#!/bin/bash
exec > /root/bootstrap.log 2>&1
set -x
SCR=/media/sf_bootstrap/autostart/*activate_autostart.sh
while [ ! -f \$SCR ];do sleep 1;done
bash \$SCR
rm -v \$SCR' > /etc/rc2.d/S40osbash; chmod 755 /etc/rc2.d/S40osbash;" | chroot /target /bin/bash;

commit_message:
Remove absolute path in KillFilter for metadata-proxy

This commit fix the problem of killing neutron-ns-metadata-proxy
when running in Virtual Environment.

Change-Id: I987dd87e19c218846a48e58b61679b4153d97f66
Closes-bug: #1363773
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/96/118296/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kill_metadata: KillFilter, root, python, -9 kill_metadata7: KillFilter, root, python2.7, -9 kill_metadata6: KillFilter, root, python2.6, -9

subject: Add transactional test support to provisioning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-10 23:58:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/8b7ae0f54e2eaf924e017552fe7a8e7135824cfb', 'message': 'Add transactional test support to provisioning

This patch further reorganizes ProvisionedDatabase
such that it now can maintain a single ProvisionedDatabase
instance across a named "scope".  A "scope" refers
to a series of test runs which can all safely share the
same database schema as well as optional fixture data.

When a test specifies a non-None "scope", the test
is run within a special context that redirects
engine and connection use to a new series of objects
based on a hierarchy called NonCommittingConnectable.
This object produces a facade that behaves like
SQLAlchemy Engine, Connection and Transaction objects
to the degree necessary for a typical database round-trip
test, but ensures that all operations run within a
single transaction that is never committed.   To allow
tests to do real rollbacks, savepoints are used, and the
transaction container always maintains a savepoint
as well for this purpose.

As tests run, if each successive test indicates the
same "scope" as the previous, the database is not dropped,
and the same schema is re-used; all changes to this schema
since the last test ran will have been rolled back.

When a change in scope occurs between tests, the
"drop all objects" routine is run, again so that the
database is not actually dropped, but is instead cleared
of all objects built within it.

Currently, the behavior of ProvisionedDatabase
as a persistent object between tests is only meaningful within
the span of a testr run that calls upon the
testr "instance_execute" and related hooks.  If these
hooks are not called, such as if the tests are run
via a different test runner, or from testtools directly,
there is currently no way for the
provisioning system to have an indication to drop
databases when all tests are complete, so without
instance_execute setting up OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the
old behavior of dropping the named database after
each test still takes place.  The ProvisionedDatabase
instance ties its own lifecycle to that of the named database
which it creates; so when dropping the database, the
ProvisionedDatabase itself removes it from the lookup.
On the next lookup for that type of database, a new
ProvisionedDatabase will replace it.

The default scope for any test is None, which
indicates that the scoping feature is not used for
those tests.  However, assuming testr has specified
OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the ProvisionedDatabase instance is now
persistent across runs for these tests as well, but at
the end of each test it now runs the "drop all objects"
routine, rather than dropping the whole database.

Partial-Bug: #1339206
Change-Id: I3bca012e2c7655b60cde7085ea55df365219edba

instance ties its own lifecycle to that of the named database
which it creates; so when dropping the database, the
ProvisionedDatabase itself removes it from the lookup.

persistent across runs for these tests as well, but at

commit_message:
Add transactional test support to provisioning

This patch further reorganizes ProvisionedDatabase
such that it now can maintain a single ProvisionedDatabase
instance across a named "scope".  A "scope" refers
to a series of test runs which can all safely share the
same database schema as well as optional fixture data.

When a test specifies a non-None "scope", the test
is run within a special context that redirects
engine and connection use to a new series of objects
based on a hierarchy called NonCommittingConnectable.
This object produces a facade that behaves like
SQLAlchemy Engine, Connection and Transaction objects
to the degree necessary for a typical database round-trip
test, but ensures that all operations run within a
single transaction that is never committed.   To allow
tests to do real rollbacks, savepoints are used, and the
transaction container always maintains a savepoint
as well for this purpose.

As tests run, if each successive test indicates the
same "scope" as the previous, the database is not dropped,
and the same schema is re-used; all changes to this schema
since the last test ran will have been rolled back.

When a change in scope occurs between tests, the
"drop all objects" routine is run, again so that the
database is not actually dropped, but is instead cleared
of all objects built within it.

Currently, the behavior of ProvisionedDatabase
as a persistent object between tests is only meaningful within
the span of a testr run that calls upon the
testr "instance_execute" and related hooks.  If these
hooks are not called, such as if the tests are run
via a different test runner, or from testtools directly,
there is currently no way for the
provisioning system to have an indication to drop
databases when all tests are complete, so without
instance_execute setting up OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the
old behavior of dropping the named database after
each test still takes place.  The ProvisionedDatabase
instance ties its own lifecycle to that of the named database
which it creates; so when dropping the database, the
ProvisionedDatabase itself removes it from the lookup.
On the next lookup for that type of database, a new
ProvisionedDatabase will replace it.

The default scope for any test is None, which
indicates that the scoping feature is not used for
those tests.  However, assuming testr has specified
OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the ProvisionedDatabase instance is now
persistent across runs for these tests as well, but at
the end of each test it now runs the "drop all objects"
routine, rather than dropping the whole database.

Partial-Bug: #1339206
Change-Id: I3bca012e2c7655b60cde7085ea55df365219edba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/53/113153/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import six from oslotest import base as oslo_test_base from sqlalchemy import engine from sqlalchemy import schema from sqlalchemy import types from oslo.db import exception from oslo.db.sqlalchemy import provision from oslo.db.sqlalchemy import test_base from oslo.db.sqlalchemy import utils class FakeFailureException(Exception): pass class RetainSchemaTest(oslo_test_base.BaseTestCase): DRIVER = "sqlite" def _provision_fixture(self, **kw): try: fixture = provision.ProvisionedDatabase.get( self.DRIVER, **kw ) except exception.BackendNotAvailable: msg = '%s backend is not available.' % self.DRIVER self.skip(msg) else: self.addCleanup(fixture.dispose, is_external_manager=True) return fixture def setUp(self): super(RetainSchemaTest, self).setUp() metadata = schema.MetaData() self.test_table = schema.Table( 'test_table', metadata, schema.Column('x', types.Integer), schema.Column('y', types.Integer), mysql_engine='InnoDB' ) def generate_schema(engine): metadata.create_all(engine, checkfirst=False) self.mock_test = mock.Mock( generate_schema=mock.Mock(side_effect=generate_schema) ) def test_fixed_scope(self): fixture = test_base.DbFixture(self.mock_test) gen_schema = self.mock_test.generate_schema fixture = self._provision_fixture( generate_schema=gen_schema, db_token=provision._random_ident() ) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, False) self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 1) self._test_transaction(fixture, 2, False) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, True) self._test_transaction(fixture, 3, False) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, False) self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 1) def test_multiple_scopes(self): fixture = test_base.DbFixture(self.mock_test) gen_schema = self.mock_test.generate_schema fixture = self._provision_fixture( generate_schema=gen_schema, db_token=provision._random_ident() ) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, False, scope="1") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 1) self._test_transaction(fixture, 2, False, scope="1") self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, True, scope="1") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 1) self._test_transaction(fixture, 2, False, scope="2") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 2) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, False, scope="2") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 2) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, False, scope=None) self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 3) self._test_transaction(fixture, 0, True, scope=None) self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 4) self._test_transaction(fixture, 1, False, scope="2") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 5) self._test_transaction(fixture, 2, False, scope="2") self.assertEqual(gen_schema.call_count, 5) def _test_transaction( self, fixture, num_rollbacks, raise_issue, scope="RetainSchemaTest"): fixture.provision(scope) self.mock_test.engine = fixture.engine try: if scope: # scope is specified, we should be in a rollback wrapper self.assertIsInstance( fixture.engine, utils.NonCommittingConnectable) else: # no scope, should be a real Engine self.assertIsInstance(fixture.engine, engine.Engine) # test that we start with a built and empty schema rows = self.mock_test.engine.execute(self.test_table.select()) self.assertEqual(rows.fetchall(), []) # connect and run some number of rollbacks with self.mock_test.engine.connect() as conn: for rollback in six.moves.range(num_rollbacks): trans = conn.begin() conn.execute( self.test_table.insert(), {"x": 1, "y": 2} ) trans.rollback() trans = conn.begin() conn.execute( self.test_table.insert(), {"x": 2, "y": 3} ) if raise_issue: # test that aborting out of the commit # doesn't impact things raise FakeFailureException("test failed") trans.commit() except FakeFailureException: pass finally: fixture.dispose() class MySQLRetainSchemaTest(RetainSchemaTest): DRIVER = "mysql" class PostgresqlRetainSchemaTest(RetainSchemaTest): DRIVER = "postgresql"

subject: Add support for per-test-run database provisioning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-29 22:36:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/af8f7027c3a7ad626a84021295d106f1ad7459f7', 'message': 'Use testr instance provisioning to lazily create databases

This patch makes use of testr's instance_provision utility
to provide for on-demand database backends that then stay
persistent for the remainder of the individual test process.
During provisioning, "oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision echo"
generates random database identifiers, but doesn't actually
create real databases.   As these identifiers are passed to
test processes via OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the ProvisionedDatabase()
object will emit CREATE DATABASE for a given token when
a database of that backend and token is first requested; the
database then stays created until the testr instance dispose
phase, and ProvisionedDatabase also holds onto the Engine
so that expensive engine-initialization is kept to a minimum.
After test completion, testr calls into
"oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision drop" with each name, whereupon
the databases given are dropped only if they exist.

Control of database connectivity remains via the
OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION environment variable.  When not
set, connectivity defaults to sqlite://, plus those backends
found to be available using "opportunistic" naming conventions.
When the variable is present, it provides a semicolon-delimited
list of URLs, and only those URLs will be used for initial
connectivity.

Change-Id: Ibaaefcef2678cc5b985e7c00f05f91b6f02de3f8
Partially-Closes-Bug: 1339206

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2014-08-08 15:26:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/b8be6e7b41a57137e56039b9606a01492f88dc7e', 'message': 'Use testr instance provisioning to lazily create databases

This patch makes use of testr's instance_provision utility
to provide for on-demand database backends that then stay
persistent for the remainder of the individual test process.
During provisioning, "oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision echo"
generates random database identifiers, but doesn't actually
create real databases.   As these identifiers are passed to
test processes via OSLO_SCHEMA_TOKEN, the ProvisionedDatabase()
object will emit CREATE DATABASE for a given token when
a database of that backend and token is first requested; the
database then stays created until the testr instance dispose
phase, and ProvisionedDatabase also holds onto the Engine
so that expensive engine-initialization is kept to a minimum.
After test completion, testr calls into
"oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision drop" with each name, whereupon
the databases given are dropped only if they exist.

Control of database connectivity remains via the
OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION environment variable.  When not
set, connectivity defaults to sqlite://, plus those backends
found to be available using "opportunistic" naming conventions.
When the variable is present, it provides a semicolon-delimited
list of URLs, and only those URLs will be used for initial
connectivity.

Change-Id: Ibaaefcef2678cc5b985e7c00f05f91b6f02de3f8
Partial-Bug: #1339206
